(Taste the sauce at this point and adjust for salt and spice, as desired.) Using the back of a spoon, make four craters in the mixture, large enough to hold an egg. Crack one egg into each of the craters. Cover the skillet and simmer for 5-7 minutes, until the eggs have set. Serve immediately with crusty bread or pita.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of chili powder and paprika can slightly increase metabolism due to their thermogenic properties. However, this effect is moderate.

boost_energy.explanation: Eggs provide protein and healthy fats, onions and peppers offer carbohydrates, and olive oil adds healthy fats. This combination supports sustained energy levels.

enhance_focus.explanation: While eggs offer some choline which can support brain health, the overall dish is not rich in specific ingredients traditionally used in TCM to enhance focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Tomatoes, garlic, and peppers are rich in vitamins, particularly vitamin C, and antioxidants, which strengthen the immune system. Garlic is known for its immune-boosting and antiviral properties, making it particularly effective in this dish.

improve_mobility.explanation: The dish does not significantly include ingredients specifically known in TCM to improve joint health or mobility, such as gelatinous meats or collagen-rich ingredients.

detox.explanation: Garlic is known for its detoxifying qualities, and tomatoes provide antioxidants that can assist in detoxification processes. However, the dish is not particularly focused on cleansing ingredients.

enhance_mood.explanation: While the dish is nutritious and may indirectly support mood through balanced energy, it lacks specific mood-enhancing herbs or ingredients used in TCM.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish is not notably calming or sleep-inducing in TCM, as it lacks specific ingredients like lotus seeds or walnuts known for such qualities.

52903.strInstructions:
Melt the butter with the oil in a large heavy-based pan. Add the onions and fry with the lid on for 10 mins until soft. Sprinkle in the sugar and cook for 20 mins more, stirring frequently, until caramelised. The onions should be really golden, full of flavour and soft when pinched between your fingers. Take care towards the end to ensure that they don’t burn.
Add the garlic for the final few mins of the onions’ cooking time, then sprinkle in the flour and stir well. Increase the heat and keep stirring as you gradually add the wine, followed by the hot stock. Cover and simmer for 15-20 mins.
To serve, turn on the grill, and toast the bread. Ladle the soup into heatproof bowls. Put a slice or two of toast on top of the bowls of soup, and pile on the cheese. Grill until melted. Alternatively, you can complete the toasts under the grill, then serve them on top.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Olive oil may contribute slightly to metabolism support due to its healthy fats, but the high sugar and butter content do not strongly align with metabolism boosting from a TCM perspective.

boost_energy.explanation: The dish contains ingredients like garlic and onions, which may enhance energy levels slightly, but the presence of heavy elements like cheese and butter counterbalances it.

enhance_focus.explanation: There are no significant amounts of ingredients known in TCM to enhance focus specifically, such as ginseng or gotu kola.

improve_immunity.explanation: Onions (1 kg) and garlic (4 cloves) are prominent in this recipe and are recognized in TCM for their capacity to improve immunity. Onions are warming and help the Lung and Stomach chi, supporting the body in fighting off colds and infections. Garlic is considered to promote Yang and boost immune function, mainly by clearing internal dampness and toxicity. The beef stock provides nourishment which bolsters general vitality.

improve_mobility.explanation: While moderate in nutrient content, ingredients such as cheese and bread provide calcium and energy, which are not directly aligned with improving joint health or enhancing mobility.

detox.explanation: Garlic has detoxifying properties according to TCM, aiding in clearing toxins from the body, but the overall dish is focused more on richness rather than cleansing.

enhance_mood.explanation: While hearty and comforting, the dish lacks specific mood-enhancing TCM ingredients such as jujube dates or walnuts.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Emphasis on high-fat cheese and butter, along with wine, does not support relaxation or sleep quality enhancing per TCM guidelines.

52899.strInstructions:
Put the almonds into a small bowl and pour over boiling water to just cover. Leave for 5 mins then drain in a sieve and leave to dry.
Preheat the oven to 180C/160 C fan/Gas Mark 4. Line a deep loose-based 20cm cake tin with baking parchment.
Put the butter in a large bowl and beat well until soft. Add the sugar and beat until light and fluffy. Stir in the orange zest and apricot jam.
Sieve together the flour and baking powder. Add the eggs to the creamed butter and sugar, a little at a time, beating well between each addition. If the mixture starts to curdle, stir in a little flour.
Add the remaining flour and ground almonds and mix well. Mix in the milk and then add the dried fruit and cherries and mix gently together.
Spoon the mixture into the prepared tin and spread level using the back of a spoon. Arrange the whole almonds close together in neat circles on the top of the cake. Bake in the oven for 45 mins.
Lower the oven temperature to 160C/140 C fan/Gas Mark 3 and cook for a further 60–80 minutes. Check the cake after 50 minutes by inserting a wooden or metal skewer into the cake. When it’s done it should have just a few crumbs attached. Check every 10 minutes - it’s important not to overcook this cake so the centre will be a little soft.
When cooked, remove the cake briefly from the oven, put the milk and sugar into a small pan and heat gently until the sugar has dissolved. Brush over the top of the cake and return the cake to the oven for 2-3 mins. Remove and allow the cake to cool in the tin. When quite cold remove from the tin and wrap in foil and keep for at least 2 days before cutting.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of orange zest provides a moderate metabolic boost due to its citrus nature, which in TCM is believed to support the movement of Qi and aid in digestion. However, the high sugar and fat content, mainly from butter and sugar, do not significantly contribute to enhancing metabolism, and therefore this option receives a lower score.

boost_energy.explanation: Primary energy-boosting benefit derives from the high levels of almonds (both whole and ground), dried fruits, and eggs, which are rich in protein and healthy fats. In TCM, almonds are believed to support the lungs and enhance energy. The combination of sugars and fruits contributes to quick energy release, aligning with TCM's understanding of providing a quick Qi boost.

enhance_focus.explanation: The use of almonds could potentially contribute to enhancing focus, as they contain brain-supporting nutrients like vitamin E. However, the high sugar content may lead to fluctuations in energy levels, making it a less reliable source for stable focus enhancement.

improve_immunity.explanation: Orange zest and dried fruits provide vitamin C and antioxidants, which can support immune function. In TCM, these characteristics align with enhancing the Wei Qi (defensive Qi) to ward off illnesses. Although beneficial, they do not dominate the recipe in terms of quantity.

improve_mobility.explanation: While almonds provide calcium and magnesium, which are essential for bone health, the overall composition and focus of the recipe do not primarily support mobility or joint health as characterized by TCM principles. Other ingredients dilute this potential benefit.

detox.explanation: The detoxifying potential is minimal because the sugar and butter content overshadow the small detox benefit from orange zest. TCM does not prioritize dessert-like elements for detox support, which impacts the scoring here.

enhance_mood.explanation: The sweet taste from apricot jam, sugar, and the pleasant aroma from orange zest may elevate mood according to TCM. These ingredients can uplift the spirit (Shen) temporarily, but due to high sugar, this benefit is not long-lasting.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Almonds may contribute to aiding sleep due to their magnesium content, but the recipe's high sugar may counteract any potential calming effect needed for enhancing sleep, resulting in a lower score.

52844.strInstructions:
Heat the oil in a large saucepan. Use kitchen scissors to snip the bacon into small pieces, or use a sharp knife to chop it on a chopping board. Add the bacon to the pan and cook for just a few mins until starting to turn golden. Add the onion, celery and carrot, and cook over a medium heat for 5 mins, stirring occasionally, until softened.
Add the garlic and cook for 1 min, then tip in the mince and cook, stirring and breaking it up with a wooden spoon, for about 6 mins until browned all over.
Stir in the tomato purée and cook for 1 min, mixing in well with the beef and vegetables. Tip in the chopped tomatoes. Fill each can half full with water to rinse out any tomatoes left in the can, and add to the pan. Add the honey and season to taste. Simmer for 20 mins.
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. To assemble the lasagne, ladle a little of the ragu sauce into the bottom of the roasting tin or casserole dish, spreading the sauce all over the base. Place 2 sheets of lasagne on top of the sauce overlapping to make it fit, then repeat with more sauce and another layer of pasta. Repeat with a further 2 layers of sauce and pasta, finishing with a layer of pasta.
Put the crème fraîche in a bowl and mix with 2 tbsp water to loosen it and make a smooth pourable sauce. Pour this over the top of the pasta, then top with the mozzarella. Sprinkle Parmesan over the top and bake for 25–30 mins until golden and bubbling. Serve scattered with basil, if you like.

boost_metabolism.explanation: This lasagne recipe contains ingredients such as garlic, which is known to support metabolism in TCM by promoting the flow of Qi. However, the amount of high-fat cheeses and meat may hinder metabolism-boosting properties, resulting in a moderate score.

boost_energy.explanation: The dish contains beef (a source of Qi or energy in TCM), and carrots which are believed to strengthen the spleen and replenish energy. Olive oil and garlic contribute to the warming nature of the dish, which can invigorate Yang and further boost energy levels. The relative amount of meat compared to other ingredients gives this a higher score.

enhance_focus.explanation: While not specifically targeting focus, the presence of celery and carrots can support mental clarity by nourishing the spleen and calming the mind. Minimal amounts of these ingredients provide modest benefits in this area.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic, onions, and tomatoes are key ingredients in this recipe that enhance immune function due to their ability to expel toxins and warm the digestive system. Still, the predominant meat and cheese ingredients do not significantly contribute to this aspect, making the dish moderately immune-boosting.

improve_mobility.explanation: While the dish contains some beneficial vegetables, the heavy use of meat, cheese, and pasta does not align well with promoting joint flexibility and mobility, thus contributing minimally to improving mobility.

detox.explanation: Tomatoes are known for their detoxifying properties in TCM, aiding in clearing heat and toxins from the blood. However, the rich and heavy nature of lasagne limits the detoxifying capability of this dish, resulting in a moderate score.

enhance_mood.explanation: This recipe contains honey and basil, which can soothe the liver and promote calmness. The rich flavors of cheese can also provide comfort, thus slightly enhancing mood. Combined with the pleasing texture of the dish, it offers a good score for mood enhancement.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish contains basil, which can calm the spirit according to TCM. However, due to the heavy and rich ingredients like cheese and red meat, which can produce heat and restlessness, it might not be conducive to aiding sleep quality, yielding a lower score.

52993.strMeal: Honey Balsamic Chicken with Crispy Broccoli & Potatoes
52993.strInstructions:
2 Servings

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Wash and dry all produce. Cut potatoes into 1/2-inch-thick wedges. Toss on one side of a baking sheet with a drizzle of oil, salt, and pepper. (For 4 servings, spread potatoes out across entire sheet.) Roast on top rack for 5 minutes (we'll add the broccoli then). 

2. Meanwhile, cut broccoli florets into bite-size pieces, if necessary. Peel and finely chop garlic. In a small microwave-safe bowl, combine 1 TBSP olive oil (2 TBSP for 4 servings) and half the garlic. Microwave until garlic sizzles, 30 seconds. 

3. Once potatoes have roasted 5 minutes, remove sheet from oven and add broccoli to empty side; carefully toss with garlic oil, salt, and pepper. (For 4 servings, add broccoli to a second sheet.) Continue roasting until potatoes and broccoli are browned and crispy, 15-20 minutes more. 

4. While veggies roast, pat chicken dry with paper towels; season all over with salt and pepper. Heat a drizzle of oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Add chicken and cook until browned and cooked through, 5-6 minutes per side. (If chicken browns too quickly, reduce heat to medium.) Turn off heat; set chicken aside to rest. Wash out pan. 

5. Heat pan used for chicken over medium-high heat. Add a drizzle of oil and remaining garlic; cook until fragrant, 30 seconds. Stir in vinegar, honey, stock concentrate, and 1/4 cup water (1/3 cup for 4 servings). Simmer until thick and glossy, 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in 1 TBSP butter (2 TBSP for 4). Season with salt and pepper. 

6. Return chicken to pan and turn to coat in glaze. Divide chicken, broccoli, and potatoes between plates. Spoon any remaining glaze over chicken and serve.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Garlic and broccoli have metabolism-boosting properties in TCM, but their quantity in this recipe is relatively small compared to the overall meal.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of chicken, potatoes, and honey provides a good source of energy due to the proteins, carbohydrates, and natural sugars. However, the energy boost might not be sustained as the focus is not on long-term energy-enhancing ingredients.

enhance_focus.explanation: While garlic may aid in focus by improving circulation, the recipe lacks a strong focus-enhancing component like omega-3 fatty acids or ginseng, both of which are more traditionally acknowledged in TCM for cognitive benefits.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic is known in TCM for its ability to strengthen the immune system due to its antibacterial and antiviral properties. Broccoli supports the immune system with its high vitamin C content. The immune-boosting properties of garlic are emphasized by the method of cooking where it is both used fresh and sautéed, maximizing its health benefits.

improve_mobility.explanation: Chicken provides collagen, which can aid in joint health, and the use of olive oil offers anti-inflammatory benefits. However, these ingredients are not present in significant amounts to strongly influence mobility.

detox.explanation: While broccoli can aid detoxification by supporting liver health, the recipe does not emphasize detoxifying ingredients enough to prioritally enhance detox.

enhance_mood.explanation: The sweetness from honey may offer brief mood-enhancing effects, but there are no significant amounts of ingredients known in TCM for profound mood enhancement like jujube or longan.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish lacks calming ingredients typically associated with promoting sleep, such as lotus seeds or chamomile. Thus, its potential to aid sleep quality is minimal.

52970.strInstructions:
Preheat oven to 190 C / Gas 5. Grease a 23cm round springform tin.
Cut off the hard bits from the top and bottom of the orange. Slice the orange and remove all seeds. Puree the orange with its peel in a food processor. Add one third of the sugar and the olive oil and continue to mix until well combined.
Sieve together flour and baking powder.
Beat the eggs and the remaining sugar with an electric hand mixer for at least five minutes until very fluffy. Fold in half of the flour mixture, then the orange and the vanilla, then fold in the remaining flour. Mix well but not for too long.
Pour cake mixture into prepared tin and smooth out. Bake in preheated oven for 20 minutes. Reduce the oven temperature to 160 C / Gas 2 and bake again for 30 minutes Bake until the cake is golden brown and a skewer comes out clean. Cool on a wire cake rack.

boost_metabolism.explanation: While orange does have some properties that might mildly support metabolism through its vitamin C content, its effect is not significantly pronounced compared to other metabolism-boosting ingredients.

boost_energy.explanation: The cake provides an energy boost primarily from the sugar and carbohydrate content in the flour. However, this is more of a quick energy source rather than a sustained one typically associated with energy-boosting foods.

enhance_focus.explanation: Oranges can help with focus due to their vitamin C content, which supports brain health, but it's not the primary function of this cake's recipe.

improve_immunity.explanation: Oranges are high in vitamin C, crucial for boosting immunity. While not very high in quantity, the use of a whole orange does contribute a moderate level of immune support.

improve_mobility.explanation: The ingredients in the cake do not specifically contribute to joint health or mobility.

detox.explanation: Oranges can support detoxification to some degree, however, other ingredients in the recipe such as sugar and flour do not aid in detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: The consumption of oranges, particularly in conjunction with other ingredients such as eggs, can promote a feeling of well-being and elevate mood through the synergistic effect of natural sugars and aromatic compounds. In TCM, oranges are associated with uplifting and invigorating properties.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While some ingredients like eggs contain tryptophan, which can aid in sleep, the cake mainly consists of sugar and carbohydrates, which are not particularly conducive to promoting restful sleep.

52852.strInstructions:
Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Toss the potatoes with 2 tsp oil and some seasoning. Tip onto a large baking tray, then roast for 20 mins, stirring halfway, until crisp, golden and cooked through.
Meanwhile, put eggs in a small pan of water, bring to the boil, then simmer for 8-10 mins, depending on how you like them cooked. Plunge into a bowl of cold water to cool for a few mins. Peel away the shells, then cut into halves.
In a large salad bowl, whisk together the remaining oil, red wine vinegar, capers and chopped tomatoes. Season, tip in the onion, spinach, tuna and potatoes, then gently toss together. Top with the eggs, then serve straight away.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The use of ingredients such as spinach and red wine vinegar can enhance digestion and mildly boost metabolism, though this is not the primary focus of the recipe. The small amount of vinegar promotes energy flow and digestive activity, which can positively influence metabolic rates.

boost_energy.explanation: The recipe features tuna as a primary ingredient, which is highly valued in TCM for its ability to nourish the Qi (vital energy). Additionally, spinach and eggs are nutrient-rich and replenishing, making this dish particularly beneficial for enhancing vitality and combating fatigue.

enhance_focus.explanation: Spinach and eggs contain nutrients that can support cognitive function, though the amount and combination of ingredients in this recipe are not specifically targeted toward improving mental clarity or focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Spinach and eggs contribute to strengthening the immune system with important vitamins and minerals. Tuna provides selenium, which supports immune function, but the overall recipe is not primarily focused on immune health.

improve_mobility.explanation: Although eggs can contribute to bone health, the majority of the ingredients do not specifically target joint flexibility or bone support, resulting in a lower score for improving mobility.

detox.explanation: Red wine vinegar and spinach have mild detoxifying properties. However, detoxification is not the primary goal of this dish, and other detoxifying ingredients are not present in significant amounts.

enhance_mood.explanation: The inclusion of mood-enhancing ingredients like eggs, which contain amino acids supporting neurotransmitter production, provides some benefit to mood elevation but does not make this the central focus.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While eggs contain nutrients that can support sleep regulation, ingredients in this dish do not specifically target or enhance sleep quality significantly.

52839.strInstructions:
Mix the dressing ingredients in a small bowl and season with salt and pepper. Set aside.

Cook the pasta according to the packet instructions. Add the sugar snap peas for the last minute or so of cooking time.

Meanwhile, heat the oil in a wok or large frying pan, toss in the garlic and chilli and cook over a fairly gentle heat for about 30 seconds without letting the garlic brown. Tip in the prawns and cook over a high heat, stirring frequently, for about 3 minutes until they turn pink.

Add the tomatoes and cook, stirring occasionally, for 3 minutes until they just start to soften. Drain the pasta and sugar snaps well, then toss into the prawn mixture. Tear in the basil leaves, stir, and season with salt and pepper.

Serve with salad leaves drizzled with the lime dressing, and warm crusty bread.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The dish contains red chili and king prawns. Chili is known to have a warming and stimulating effect in TCM, which can facilitate metabolism. However, the primary ingredient, linguine pasta, is more neutral and doesn't strongly influence metabolism.

boost_energy.explanation: This recipe is rich in energy-boosting ingredients, primarily due to the combination of king prawns, garlic, and lime. In TCM, prawns are believed to enhance yang energy, which translates into vitality and stamina. Garlic is known for its ability to invigorate qi (energy flow), and lime adds a refreshing and uplifting effect. This makes the recipe particularly effective in replenishing energy.

enhance_focus.explanation: Certain ingredients like basil and lime may offer slight mental clarity benefits, but the main focus of the ingredients doesn't strongly enhance cognitive functions.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic is renowned in TCM for its ability to strengthen the immune system due to its warming properties, and the cherry tomatoes offer vitamins that support immunity. However, the presence of other significant immune-optimizing ingredients is limited.

improve_mobility.explanation: While prawns can support yang energy, which indirectly helps mobility, and the basil has some anti-inflammatory properties, the dish lacks ingredients specifically aimed at enhancing joint or bone health.

detox.explanation: The lime juice and basil add a mild detoxifying effect, however, the dish is generally not composed of significant detoxifying ingredients to warrant a high score.

enhance_mood.explanation: The bright flavors from lime and basil, alongside the quick cooking method and fresh ingredients, can elevate the mood slightly, but it's not composed primarily of mood-enhancing ingredients in TCM terms.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish contains stimulating ingredients like chili and garlic, which may not support sleep quality. There's an absence of calming or sedative ingredients to promote restful sleep.

52827.strInstructions:
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6, then roast the peanuts on a baking tray for 5 mins until golden brown. When cool enough to handle, roughly chop. Reduce oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Heat 2 tbsp coconut cream in a large casserole dish with a lid. Add the curry paste and fry for 1 min, then stir in the beef and fry until well coated and sealed. Stir in the rest of the coconut with half a can of water, the potatoes, onion, lime leaves, cinnamon, tamarind, sugar, fish sauce and most of the peanuts. Bring to a simmer, then cover and cook for 2 hrs in the oven until the beef is tender.
Sprinkle with sliced chilli and the remaining peanuts, then serve straight from the dish with jasmine rice.

ingredients.chilli: 1 red deseeded and finely sliced, to serve

boost_metabolism.explanation: The inclusion of chili contributes to a slight metabolic boost due to its thermogenic properties, but the dish primarily focuses on rich, hearty ingredients rather than metabolism enhancement.

boost_energy.explanation: The beef, potatoes, and jasmine rice provide a good source of carbohydrates and proteins that can supply energy. However, they are moderate in promoting overall energy boost due to the rich, heavy nature of the dish.

enhance_focus.explanation: There are no significant ingredients known for enhancing focus or brain function. The dish is more centered around heartiness and flavor, rather than cognitive enhancement.

improve_immunity.explanation: Cinnamon and chili can support immunity with their anti-inflammatory and circulation-boosting properties, but their quantities are not dominant enough to provide a strong immune boost.

improve_mobility.explanation: While the dish includes beef, which provides protein necessary for joint health, it's not specifically formulated to support joint flexibility or bone health.

detox.explanation: Lime leaves and tamarind have mild detoxifying properties, but they are not in high enough quantities to make detoxing a primary benefit.

enhance_mood.explanation: The rich, warm flavor profile of massaman curry, including aromatic cinnamon and chili, can elevate mood by providing comfort and warmth, both of which are significant in TCM for emotional well-being. Additionally, peanuts and coconut cream add richness that can be emotionally satisfying, making the dish comforting. This aligns with TCM principles of balancing Qi and gently uplifting spirits through harmonizing flavors.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Although the meal may provide comfort, which can aid in better sleep, it lacks specific ingredients known for promoting sleep quality, like those that are calming and sedative in nature.

52944.strInstructions:
Rinse fish; rub with lemon or lime, seasoned with salt and pepper or use your favorite seasoning. I used creole seasoning. Set aside or place in the oven to keep it warm until sauce is ready.

In large skillet heat oil over medium heat, until hot, add the fish, cook each side- for about 5-7 minutes until cooked through and crispy on both sides. Remove fish and set aside. Drain oil and leave about 2-3 tablespoons of oil
Add, bay leave, garlic and ginger, stir-fry for about a minute making sure the garlic does not burn
Then add onion, bell peppers, thyme, scotch bonnet, sugar, all spice-continue stirring for about 2-3 minutes. Add vinegar, mix an adjust salt and pepper according to preference. Let it simmer for about 2 more minutes. 

Discard bay leave, thyme spring and serve over fish with a side of this bammy. You may make the sauce about 2 days in advance.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of ginger, garlic, and red and yellow peppers can slightly boost metabolism due to their known warming and digestive aid properties. However, the amount in the recipe may not make a significant impact.

boost_energy.explanation: Ginger and red snapper provide some energy-boosting properties due to their ability to enhance blood circulation and provide protein, respectively. However, the preparation method involves frying, which might offset energy by adding heaviness.

enhance_focus.explanation: Garlic, although known for improving blood circulation, which can aid focus, is present in a minimal amount, limiting its potential effect on cognitive function.

improve_immunity.explanation: The combination of ginger, garlic, and thyme, along with vegetables like bell peppers and onions, contributes to strengthening the immune system. These ingredients are known in TCM for their protective qualities, assisting in warding off colds and enhancing the body's defenses, making this the primary benefit.

improve_mobility.explanation: The red snapper provides essential fatty acids which can aid in maintaining joint health, but there are limited components specifically targeting mobility in this recipe.

detox.explanation: The use of lime, ginger, and vinegar offers mild detoxification properties by aiding digestion and cleansing. However, the dish does not heavily focus on detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: While spicy foods like scotch bonnet peppers can release endorphins to enhance mood, the other components are not specifically mood-enhancing.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The recipe contains no significant ingredients known for inducing sleep or relaxation, hence a lower score for sleep quality enhancement.

53030.strInstructions:
Mix the flour and salt then pour one cup of water and start kneading.
If you feel the dough is still not coming together or too dry, gradually add the remaining water until you get a dough that is very elastic so that when you pull it and it won’t be torn.
Let the dough rest for just 10 minutes then divide the dough into 6-8 balls depending on the size you want for your feteer.
Warm up the butter/ghee or oil you are using and pour into a deep bowl.
Immerse the dough balls into the warm butter. Let it rest for 15 to 20 minutes.
Preheat oven to 550F.
Stretch the first ball with your hands on a clean countertop. Stretch it as thin as you can, the goal here is to see your countertop through the dough.
Fold the dough over itself to form a square brushing in between folds with the butter mixture.
Set aside and start making the next ball.
Stretch the second one thin as we have done for the first ball.
Place the previous one on the middle seam side down. Fold the outer one over brushing with more butter mixture as you fold. Set aside.
Keep doing this for the third and fourth balls. Now we have one ready, place on a 10 inch baking/pie dish seam side down and brush the top with more butter.
Repeat for the remaining 4 balls to make a second one. With your hands lightly press the folded feteer to spread it on the baking dish.
Place in preheated oven for 10 minutes when the feteer starts puffing turn on the broiler to brown the top.
When it is done add little butter on top and cover so it won’t get dry.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The main ingredients, flour, and a significant amount of butter and olive oil, are rich in calories which could modestly support metabolism but do not particularly target metabolic processes.

boost_energy.explanation: The high calorie content from flour and butter in Feteer Meshaltet provides ample energy. In TCM, wheat flour can boost Qi, offering sustained energy levels, especially when baked. The cooking method through baking further activates the warming nature of the dish, promoting energy enhancement.

enhance_focus.explanation: The ingredients lack specific nutrients or herbs known to boost brain function or enhance mental clarity. Therefore, it contributes low to this benefit.

improve_immunity.explanation: While the ingredients provide general nourishment, they lack specific immune-boosting components, offering minimal direct support to the immune system from a TCM viewpoint.

improve_mobility.explanation: The recipe doesn't include ingredients like bone broth or gelatin known for supporting joint and bone health, thus offering negligible benefits for mobility.

detox.explanation: The wheat and fats present in the dish are not known for detoxification purposes in TCM, thus providing minimal detox capability.

enhance_mood.explanation: Butter, which provides a comforting and calming experience, could mildly improve mood by promoting warmth and satisfaction, but lacks specific mood-enhancing properties.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The calming effect from butter might slightly support better sleep indirectly, but this dish lacks specific sleep-aiding herbs or relaxing qualities needed to strongly support sleep.

52855.strInstructions:
In a bowl, mash the banana with a fork until it resembles a thick purée. Stir in the eggs, baking powder and vanilla.
Heat a large non-stick frying pan or pancake pan over a medium heat and brush with half the oil. Using half the batter, spoon two pancakes into the pan, cook for 1-2 mins each side, then tip onto a plate. Repeat the process with the remaining oil and batter. Top the pancakes with the pecans and raspberries.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Banana and eggs provide essential nutrients such as potassium and protein which help in maintaining healthy metabolism. Pecans contain healthy fats that can moderately support metabolic processes, but the overall dish is not primarily focused on boosting metabolism.

boost_energy.explanation: Bananas are rich in carbohydrates, particularly natural sugars like glucose, fructose, and sucrose, which provide an immediate energy boost. Eggs supply protein that sustains energy levels. Pecans also provide healthy fats and calories, contributing to lasting energy. This combination makes the meal energizing, particularly after breakfast.

enhance_focus.explanation: Eggs contain choline, which is beneficial for brain health and cognitive function, potentially enhancing focus. However, the amounts may not be significant enough to notably enhance focus when consumed in this form.

improve_immunity.explanation: Raspberries are rich in Vitamin C, an antioxidant that supports the immune system. However, the quantity of raspberries is less compared to other main ingredients, limiting the dish's overall impact on immunity.

improve_mobility.explanation: Pecans provide healthy fats which support joint health, but there aren’t significant quantities or other supportive ingredients specifically enhancing mobility.

detox.explanation: Raspberries have detoxifying properties due to their fiber content, but the dish is not focused on ingredients that primarily promote detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: Bananas can enhance mood due to their high levels of tryptophan, which converts into serotonin. The sweet taste of the pancakes also contributes to mood elevation. Although positive, the mood-enhancing effect is secondary to the energizing properties.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While bananas contain tryptophan, which can promote sleep, the dish is consumed as a breakfast and includes energy-boosting elements that are not conducive to initiating sleep.

52791.strInstructions:
Purée half the strawberries in a blender. Chop the remaining strawberries, reserving four for decoration.
Whip the double cream until stiff peaks form, then fold in the strawberry purée and crushed meringue. Fold in the chopped strawberries and ginger cordial, if using.
Spoon equal amounts of the mixture into four cold wine glasses. Serve garnished with the remaining strawberries and a sprig of mint.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The recipe primarily consists of whipped cream, meringue, and strawberries, which do not particularly support metabolism boosting. Strawberries contain some vitamin C, but the sugar content from meringue and cream does not contribute greatly to this benefit.

boost_energy.explanation: The inclusion of ginger cordial provides a mild warming effect and fluency in energy flow, according to TCM. However, the large amounts of sugar and cream mainly provide quick energy boosts, hence a moderate score.

enhance_focus.explanation: While ginger can offer a slight enhancement in cognitive function and alertness, the overall high sugar and cream content is not particularly beneficial for sustained focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Strawberries are rich in vitamin C, supporting immunity. However, due to the overshadowing of sugar and cream, the overall immune-boosting effect is moderate.

improve_mobility.explanation: There are no significant ingredients in this recipe that target joint health or improve mobility from a TCM perspective.

detox.explanation: Mint provides a slight cooling detoxification quality, yet the presence of cream and sugar counteracts most detoxifying effects.

enhance_mood.explanation: The combination of strawberries, mint, and a touch of ginger creates a refreshing dessert that can uplift mood and provides a sense of sweetness associated with feelings of satisfaction and joy. In TCM, the sweetness of strawberries and meringue can enhance feelings of happiness and contentment.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Rich, creamy desserts may provide comfort, potentially aiding relaxation, but they are not particularly conducive to improving sleep quality in TCM.

53011.strInstructions:
Cook the quinoa following the pack instructions, then rinse in cold water and drain thoroughly.

Meanwhile, mix the butter, chilli and garlic into a paste. Toss the chicken fillets in 2 tsp of the olive oil with some seasoning. Lay in a hot griddle pan and cook for 3-4 mins each side or until cooked through. Transfer to a plate, dot with the spicy butter and set aside to melt.

Next, tip the tomatoes, olives, onion, feta and mint into a bowl. Toss in the cooked quinoa. Stir through the remaining olive oil, lemon juice and zest, and season well. Serve with the chicken fillets on top, drizzled with any buttery chicken juices.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Chicken and red chilies provide protein and capsaicin, which can slightly boost metabolism. However, the presence of fats from butter and olive oil balances this effect, earning a moderate score.

boost_energy.explanation: This dish is rich in energy-boosting ingredients, primarily quinoa and chicken, which provide protein and complex carbohydrates. Quinoa, a Qi-tonifying grain, helps enhance vitality. Olive oil and mint further support energy with their nourishing qualities. The major role of quinoa and chicken in the recipe earns it a high score in energy support.

enhance_focus.explanation: Ingredients like quinoa and chicken, high in proteins, can support mental alertness and focus. The presence of omega-3 in olive oil also helps with cognitive function, but there's no substantial focus-enhancing herb or element to push the score higher.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic, mint, and lemon are known in TCM for their Wei Qi-boosting, or immune-protective, properties. The presence of these ingredients in moderate amounts provides good support for immune enhancement.

improve_mobility.explanation: The dish includes chicken, which in TCM is believed to strengthen bones and muscles. However, there are few elements specifically targeting joint health, so the score remains moderate.

detox.explanation: Lemon has detoxifying properties, and garlic is cleansing in TCM. However, these ingredients are present in smaller quantities, thus providing only a moderate detoxifying effect.

enhance_mood.explanation: Ingredients such as chicken and olive oil can elevate mood by stabilizing blood sugar and providing nourishing fats. Mint adds a refreshing quality but lacks profound mood-enhancing attributes to score higher.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While mint and olive oil possess calming properties, the presence of stimulating ingredients like red chili balances this effect, making it less impactful on sleep quality.

52890.strInstructions:
Put a deep roasting tin onto the bottom shelf of the oven, and make sure that there’s another shelf directly above it. Pull the roasting tin out on its shelf, fill two-thirds with boiling water from the kettle, then carefully slide it back in. Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Tear off a large sheet of foil and greaseproof paper (about 30 x 40cm). Sit the greaseproof on top of the foil and butter it.
Tip butter, flour and vanilla seeds into a food processor; pulse until the butter has disappeared. Tip into a mixing bowl. Stir through the suet, pour in the milk and work together with a cutlery knife until you get a sticky dough. You may need a drop more milk, depending on your flour.
Tip the dough out onto a floured surface, quickly pat together to smooth, then roll out to a square roughly 25 x 25cm. Spread the jam all over, leaving a gap along one edge, then roll up from the opposite edge. Pinch the jam-free edge into the dough where it meets, and pinch the ends roughly, too. Carefully lift onto the greased paper, join-side down (you might find a flat baking sheet helpful for this), loosely bring up the paper and foil around it, then scrunch together along the edges and ends to seal. The roly-poly will puff quite a bit during cooking so don’t wrap it tightly. Lift the parcel directly onto the rack above the tin and cook for 1 hr.
Let the pudding sit for 5 mins before unwrapping, then carefully open the foil and paper, and thickly slice to serve.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The recipe is predominantly made up of carbohydrates and fats (flour, butter, suet), which are not traditionally known to boost metabolism in TCM. There is no inclusion of ingredients like ginger or chili that are typically used to enhance metabolic rates.

boost_energy.explanation: Butter and suet provide high-calorie content, which can offer a short-term energy boost. However, they lack sustained energy release or nutrient-dense properties to significantly enhance daily energy levels.

enhance_focus.explanation: The ingredients in this dessert do not contain known brain-boosting compounds such as omega-3 fatty acids, ginkgo, or other herbs that support concentration and focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Raspberry jam offers some vitamin C, which can contribute marginally to immunity, but the overall sugar and fat content might counteract immune-boosting benefits.

improve_mobility.explanation: There are no ingredients that traditionally support joint health or bone density in this recipe, such as gelatin or turmeric.

detox.explanation: This recipe includes ingredients like butter and jam, which do not support detoxification. There are no cleansing herbs or vegetables included.

enhance_mood.explanation: The sweet taste of raspberry jam and the comforting qualities of a warm dessert can elevate mood and provide emotional comfort. In TCM, sweet flavors are associated with calming and relaxing effects.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While dairy (milk) can promote relaxation in some people, the high sugar content from the jam could potentially disrupt sleep if consumed in excess, counteracting any mild calming effects.

52874.strInstructions:
Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/Gas 2.
Toss the beef and flour together in a bowl with some salt and black pepper.
Heat a large casserole until hot, add half of the rapeseed oil and enough of the beef to just cover the bottom of the casserole.
Fry until browned on each side, then remove and set aside. Repeat with the remaining oil and beef.
Return the beef to the pan, add the wine and cook until the volume of liquid has reduced by half, then add the stock, onion, carrots, thyme and mustard, and season well with salt and pepper.
Cover with a lid and place in the oven for two hours.
Remove from the oven, check the seasoning and set aside to cool. Remove the thyme.
When the beef is cool and you're ready to assemble the pie, preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6.
Transfer the beef to a pie dish, brush the rim with the beaten egg yolks and lay the pastry over the top. Brush the top of the pastry with more beaten egg.
Trim the pastry so there is just enough excess to crimp the edges, then place in the oven and bake for 30 minutes, or until the pastry is golden-brown and cooked through.
For the green beans, bring a saucepan of salted water to the boil, add the beans and cook for 4-5 minutes, or until just tender.
Drain and toss with the butter, then season with black pepper.
To serve, place a large spoonful of pie onto each plate with some green beans alongside.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The carbohydrate content in puff pastry and plain flour offers a moderate boost to metabolism. Mustard is believed to have some metabolism-boosting properties, but overall, the recipe doesn't strongly emphasize ingredients that are known to significantly enhance metabolic rate from a TCM perspective.

boost_energy.explanation: The primary ingredients, beef and red wine, are considered energizing in TCM. Beef nourishes the Qi and builds the yang energy, vital for combatting fatigue. The moderate amount of wine also adds a warming, invigorating quality. Combined with the root vegetables like carrots and the richness from the stew, the dish can effectively enhance vitality.

enhance_focus.explanation: There are no specific ingredients in the recipe known for significantly boosting cognitive function. While nutrients supporting general health can indirectly support focus, this dish isn't optimal for enhancing mental clarity directly.

improve_immunity.explanation: Beef provides essential nutrients that support immune health in TCM, and onions and carrots are known to help clear heat and support immunity. However, the dish is not dominated by ingredients traditionally used for strengthening Wei Qi, or defensive energy.

improve_mobility.explanation: The beef and bone broth have properties that can promote joint health through nourishing the blood and yang energy. However, there are no standout ingredients specifically supporting joint flexibility or directly impacting bone health in TCM.

detox.explanation: While vegetables contribute to general health, the dish primarily focuses on rich and warming ingredients that nourish and build rather than eliminate or detoxify. It's not aligned with TCM principles for detoxification, which often require lighter foods.

enhance_mood.explanation: Red wine in moderation can have mood-enhancing properties, and warm, hearty dishes like this one can comfort and stabilize mood through blood and Qi nourishment. However, the emphasis is not explicitly on mood-enhancement ingredients.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Ingredients like onion and thyme may promote relaxation, yet the dish does not include calming herbs or foods typically used to induce sleep in TCM, such as lotus seeds or jujube.

52968.strInstructions:
1. Steps for the Meat: 
 Roast meat over medium heat for 50 minutes and salt it as you turn it.

2. Steps for Ugali:
Bring the water and salt to a boil in a heavy-bottomed saucepan. Stir in the cornmeal slowly, letting it fall through the fingers of your hand.

3. Reduce heat to medium-low and continue stirring regularly, smashing any lumps with a spoon, until the mush pulls away from the sides of the pot and becomes very thick, about 10 minutes.

4.Remove from heat and allow to cool.

5. Place the ugali into a large serving bowl. Wet your hands with water, form a ball and serve.

6. Steps for Kachumbari: Mix the tomatoes, onions, chili and coriander leaves in a bowl.

7. Serve and enjoy!

boost_metabolism.explanation: This dish has a rich protein content due to the goat meat, which can support metabolism to some extent. However, the primary cooking method of roasting is not focused on metabolic enhancement, hence a moderate score.

boost_energy.explanation: The dish prominently features goat meat, which is revered in TCM for its ability to tonify the yang energy and replenish qi. The cornflour in Ugali is carbohydrate-dense, providing essential energy, making this dish exceptionally energizing. Roasting the meat also preserves its nutrients, thereby enhancing vitality.

enhance_focus.explanation: While protein can help with sustained energy levels, leading to better focus indirectly, there are no specific ingredients targeting mental clarity or focus-enhancing properties in the recipe.

improve_immunity.explanation: Ingredients like onions and coriander have some immune-boosting effects, supporting the body's defenses. However, these are not in sufficient quantities to be the main focus.

improve_mobility.explanation: Goat meat can contribute to joint health with its protein content, which is important for tissue repair, but there are no specific herbs or spices in this recipe that focus on improving mobility directly.

detox.explanation: The dish lacks specific detoxifying ingredients such as herbs or vegetables known for their cleansing properties, leading to a lower score in this category.

enhance_mood.explanation: The combination of meat and chili may contribute to mood enhancement through increased energy and a comforting spicy flavor, but specific mood-enhancing herbs or ingredients are not present.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The ingredients and cooking methods do not include any sleep-inducing or calming elements typically recommended for improving sleep, resulting in a lower score for aiding sleep quality.

52933.strInstructions:
Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease a 10x14x2-inch baking pan.
Heat margarine in a skillet over medium heat; stir in onion. Cook and stir until onion has softened and turned translucent, about 5 minutes. Reduce heat to low and continue to cook and stir until onion is very tender and dark brown, about 40 minutes more.
Bring chicken broth to a boil in a large pot; stir in chicken breasts, reduce heat, and simmer until chicken is no longer pink at the center, about 20 minutes. Remove from heat. Remove chicken breasts to a plate using a slotted spoon; reserve broth.
Juice potatoes with an electric juicer; place dry potato flesh into a bowl and discard juice. Stir salt and pepper into potatoes; stir in enough reserved broth to make the mixture the consistency of oatmeal. Set remaining broth aside.
Spread half of potato mixture evenly into the prepared pan. Lay cooked chicken breast evenly over potatoes; scatter caramelized onion evenly over chicken. Spread remaining potato mixture over onions and chicken to cover.
Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 1 hour. Reheat chicken broth; pour over individual servings as desired.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Chicken is a good source of protein, which can slightly increase metabolic rate, but the predominant ingredient, potatoes, do not have significant metabolism-boosting properties.

boost_energy.explanation: The main ingredients of this dish, particularly chicken and potatoes, provide substantial energy and nutrition. In TCM, chicken is considered warming and nourishing, which supports energy levels, while potatoes offer substantial carbohydrates for sustained energy.

enhance_focus.explanation: There are no specific ingredients in this dish known to significantly boost focus or mental clarity from a TCM standpoint.

improve_immunity.explanation: Chicken is associated with enhancing qi and improving immunity in TCM. However, the presence of salt and butter does not significantly contribute to immune boosting.

improve_mobility.explanation: While chicken provides some protein that is generally supportive of muscle function, the dish does not contain ingredients specifically known for improving joint or bone health.

detox.explanation: This recipe lacks ingredients traditionally associated with detoxification in TCM, such as bitter or strongly cleansing foods.

enhance_mood.explanation: The warming nature of chicken could moderately enhance the mood by boosting qi, but it is not the primary purpose of the dish.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The ingredients in this dish are not particularly known for aiding sleep quality or having calming effects necessary for improved sleep.

52994.strMeal: Skillet Apple Pork Chops with Roasted Sweet Potatoes & Zucchini
52994.strInstructions:
Serves 2


1. 

Adjust racks to top and middle positions and preheat oven to 450 degrees. Wash and dry all produce. Dice sweet potatoes into 1/2-inch pieces. Toss on a baking sheet with a drizzle of oil, salt, and pepper. Roast on top rack for 12 minutes (we'll roast the zucchini then). 


2. 

Meanwhile, halve and core apple; thinly slice into half-moons. Peel and finely chop garlic. Quarter lemon. Trim and halve zucchini lengthwise; cut crosswise into 1/2-inch-thick half-moons. Toss on a second baking sheet with a drizzle of oil and a pinch of salt and pepper. Set aside. 


3. 

Pat pork dry with paper towels and season all over with salt and pepper. Heat a drizzle of oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Add pork and cook until browned and cooked through, 4-5 minutes per side. Turn off heat; transfer to a plate. 


4. 

Once sweet potatoes have roasted 12 minutes, transfer baking sheet with zucchini to middle rack and continue roasting until both veggies are browned and softened, 12-15 minutes more. 


5. 

Meanwhile, melt 1 TBSP butter (2 TBSP for 4 servings) in pan used for pork over medium-high heat. Add apple and season with salt and pepper. Cook, scraping up any browned bits from bottom of pan, until apple is slightly softened, 2-3 minutes. Add garlic; cook until fragrant, 30 seconds. Add 1/z cup water (3/4 cup for 4), stock concentrate, and 11/2 tsp sugar (3 tsp for 4). Cook, stirring, until sauce has thickened and apple is very tender, 3-5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. 


6. 

Remove pan with apple from heat; stir in 1 TBSP butter (2 TBSP for 4 servings) and a squeeze of lemon juice. Divide pork, zucchini, and sweet potatoes between plates. Top pork with glazed apple sauce. Top zucchini with a squeeze of lemon juice.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Pork and sweet potatoes provide a moderate amount of calories, and the presence of protein and healthy fats from pork and butter could contribute slightly to metabolism boosting.

boost_energy.explanation: Sweet potatoes are a rich source of carbohydrates and provide a quick energy boost. Pork also adds protein for sustained energy.

enhance_focus.explanation: While garlic and apples can support brain health marginally, they are not present in significant amounts to sharply enhance focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: The ingredients such as garlic and lemon are well-known for their immune-boosting properties. Garlic is a superfood in TCM, aiding in enhancing the body's defenses, while lemon provides vitamin C, which is critical for immunity.

improve_mobility.explanation: This meal lacks significant amounts of nutrients directly linked to joint health and mobility.

detox.explanation: Lemon and garlic have cleansing properties but are not present in high enough quantities to strongly promote detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: The presence of complex carbohydrates from sweet potatoes and the comforting nature of the pork dish may slightly elevate mood, but it's not overwhelmingly influential.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While some ingredients like garlic can have mild soothing properties, the dish does not contain significant ingredients known for enhancing sleep quality.

53067.strMeal: Stuffed Bell Peppers with Quinoa and Black Beans
53067.strInstructions:
1. Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C). Lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking dish or a similar-sized casserole dish.
2. Place the bell pepper halves in the prepared baking dish, cut side up. Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until slightly softened.
3. While the bell peppers are baking, prepare the filling. In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onion, and cook for 3-4 minutes, until softened. Add the garlic, and cook for another 1 minute, until fragrant.
4. Stir in the cooked quinoa, black beans, corn, diced tomatoes, ground cumin, chili powder, smoked paprika, salt, and pepper. Cook for 5-7 minutes, until heated through. Remove the skillet from heat, and stir in 1 cup of the shredded cheese, if using.
5. Remove the bell peppers from the oven, and carefully stuff each pepper half with the quinoa and black bean mixture. Top the stuffed peppers with the remaining 1/2 cup of shredded cheese, if using.
6. Return the stuffed peppers to the oven, and bake for another 15-20 minutes, until the cheese is melted and the peppers are tender.
7. Remove from the oven, and allow the stuffed peppers to cool for 5 minutes before serving. Garnish with fresh chopped cilantro.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The spices used, such as cumin and chili powder, can slightly enhance metabolism due to their warming nature, but their quantity is relatively low.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of quinoa and black beans provides a good source of carbohydrates and protein, which can support energy levels throughout the day.

enhance_focus.explanation: Onion and garlic may provide some benefits for brain health due to their antioxidants, but they are not in high quantities to primarily affect focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Bell peppers are rich in Vitamin C, and garlic is known as a potent immune booster; both contribute significantly to enhancing immunity according to TCM. The addition of quinoa, with its complete protein profile, helps nourish the body, providing additional supportive elements for overall immune function.

improve_mobility.explanation: This dish lacks significant ingredients traditionally known to improve joint and bone health in TCM, such as gelatinous foods or certain herbs.

detox.explanation: Garlic and cilantro have mild detoxification properties, but they occur in small amounts here. The recipe is not focused on detoxification processes primarily.

enhance_mood.explanation: Quinoa and beans could provide a steady energy source, improving mood stability, but the recipe doesn't include specific mood-enhancing herbs or spices.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The recipe contains stimulating spices like chili powder, which may not be ideal for inducing better sleep quality. There are no calming ingredients present.

53060.strInstructions: Fry the finely chopped onions and minced meat in oil. Add the salt and pepper. Grease a round baking tray and put a layer of pastry in it. Cover with a thin layer of filling and cover this with another layer of filo pastry which must be well coated in oil. Put another layer of filling and cover with pastry. When you have five or six layers, cover with filo pastry, bake at 200ºC/392ºF for half an hour and cut in quarters and serve.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The onions and pepper provide mild metabolism-boosting qualities. However, the dominant ingredients, such as minced beef and filo pastry, are not traditionally considered metabolism-enhancing in TCM.

boost_energy.explanation: Minced beef is rich in nutrients like iron and protein that can boost energy, replenish Qi, and combat fatigue. The combination with onions enhances this effect slightly, supporting vital Qi nourishment.

enhance_focus.explanation: While onions can have a mild impact on enhancing focus by nourishing the liver, the primary ingredients do not significantly contribute to mental clarity in a TCM framework.

improve_immunity.explanation: Onions are known for improving immunity in TCM due to their ability to disperse cold. However, the overall dish lacks a sufficient diversity of immune-enhancing ingredients.

improve_mobility.explanation: The dish lacks specific ingredients that support joint flexibility or bone health; hence, it scores low in mobility enhancement.

detox.explanation: Onions offer some detoxifying properties by moving Qi and clearing stagnation, but the recipe does not focus on cleansing or purifying foods.

enhance_mood.explanation: Eating beef can ground and nourish the body, potentially enhancing mood. However, this is not a primary focus of the recipe's ingredients.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The ingredients do not particularly support calming or sleep-inducing effects, though the grounded feeling after a rich meal might contribute slightly to comfort and rest.

53026.strInstructions:
oak the beans in water to cover overnight.Drain. If skinless beans are unavailable, rub to loosen the skins, then discard the skins. Pat the beans dry with a towel.
Grind the beans in a food mill or meat grinder.If neither appliance is available, process them in a food processor but only until the beans form a paste. (If blended too smoothly, the batter tends to fall apart during cooking.) Add the scallions, garlic, cilantro, cumin, baking powder, cayenne, salt, pepper, and coriander, if using.  Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
Shape the bean mixture into 1-inch balls.Flatten slightly and coat with flour.
Heat at least 1½-inches of oil over medium heat to 365 degrees.
Fry the patties in batches, turning once, until golden brown on all sides, about 5 minutes.Remove with a wire mesh skimmer or slotted spoon. Serve as part of a meze or in pita bread with tomato-cucumber salad and tahina sauce.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The broad beans, rich in protein and fiber, along with cumin, can aid in maintaining a healthy metabolism. However, since the dish involves deep-frying, it might counteract some metabolism-boosting effects.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of broad beans, garlic, and spring onions provides protein, vitamins, and antioxidants which together help improve energy levels and vitality, making it the most notable benefit of this dish.

enhance_focus.explanation: The garlic and cumin can support brain health and improve mental clarity, but their effects are not as pronounced as those that boost energy.

improve_immunity.explanation: The ingredients like garlic and parsley are known for enhancing the immune system due to their antioxidant properties. However, the preparation of deep-frying slightly reduces their efficacy.

improve_mobility.explanation: While broad beans do contain nutrients beneficial for joint health, the dish is not particularly dense in ingredients that are traditionally used for mobility such as gelatin-rich broths or bone stews.

detox.explanation: The fiber content from the beans supports detoxification, yet the deep-frying process contributes additional oils that may require the body to detoxify more than the dish inherently supports detox.

enhance_mood.explanation: Spices like cumin and cayenne pepper can enhance mood by promoting circulation, yet they are not dominant enough in quantity to make this the primary benefit.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: There are no significant ingredients in this recipe that are known to aid in sleep quality distinctly, such as calming herbs or ingredients that enhance melatonin production.

53062.strInstructions:
Mix all the ingredients for the dough together and knead well. Cover the dough and put to rise until doubled in size which should take about 2 hours. Knock back the dough and knead lightly.

Divide the dough into two equal pieces; roll each piece into an oblong about 12 inches by 8 inches. Mix the filling ingredients together and divide between the dough, spreading over each piece. Roll up the oblongs as tightly as possible to give two 12 inch sausages. Place these side by side, touching each other, on a greased baking sheet. Cover and leave to rise for about 40 minutes. Heat oven to 200ºC (425ºF). Bake for 30-35 minutes until well risen and golden brown. Bread should sound hollow when the base is tapped.

Remove from oven and brush the hot bread top with milk. Sift with a generous covering of icing sugar.

boost_metabolism.explanation: This dessert is rich in calories from ingredients like butter and sugar, which do not specifically boost metabolism. TCM does not traditionally associate these ingredients with metabolism enhancement.

boost_energy.explanation: The sugar and carbohydrates from the flour and sugar provide an immediate energy boost, though from a TCM perspective, they offer short-lived energy with potential to create imbalances if consumed excessively.

enhance_focus.explanation: Walnuts, in TCM, are believed to nourish the brain and improve focus, but they are a secondary ingredient here, limiting the impact.

52926.strInstructions:
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Boil the potato until tender, drain and mash, then leave to cool. Heat the oil in a non-stick pan, add the mince and onion and quickly fry until browned. Add the garlic, spices, stock, plenty of pepper and a little salt and mix well. Remove from the heat, stir into the potato and leave to cool.
Roll out half the pastry and line the base of a 20-23cm pie plate or flan tin. Fill with the pork mixture and brush the edges of the pastry with water. Roll out the remaining dough and cover the pie. Press the edges of the pastry to seal, trimming off the excess. Prick the top of the pastry case to allow steam to escape and glaze the top with the beaten egg.
Bake for 30 mins until the pastry is crisp and golden. Serve cut into wedges with a crisp green salad. Leftovers are good cold for lunch the next day, served with a selection of pickles.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The spices (cinnamon, allspice, nutmeg) used in small amounts may help slightly with metabolism. In TCM, these warming spices can promote Qi circulation, but their impact is minimal due to their low quantities.

boost_energy.explanation: The dish provides a high energy content thanks to its ingredients - pork (rich in Qi according to TCM), potatoes (considered an energy-giving food), and pastry. Pork in particular is nourishing and strengthening, promoting vitality and combating fatigue.

enhance_focus.explanation: Garlic and onions are known to enhance circulation and could support brain function, but the main ingredients focus more on energy and nourishment rather than mental clarity.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic and onions have properties that support the immune system due to their pungent and warm nature. However, the contribution is modest given the overall dish composition.

improve_mobility.explanation: The ingredients don't particularly enhance joint health or flexibility. However, pork provides strength to the body's muscles and sinews according to TCM, albeit not directly improving mobility.

detox.explanation: The dish is not primarily composed of foods that are traditionally used in TCM for detoxification. The richness and density of pork and pastry counteract any cleansing attributes of minor ingredients.

enhance_mood.explanation: The spices provide some uplift in mood due to their warming, aromatic properties. Pork and potatoes provide grounding energy but are not directly mood-enhancing.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The comforting and grounding nature of pork and potatoes might aid relaxation and sleep, but the low amount of sleep-aiding herbs or spices results in a moderate score.

52892.strInstructions:
First make the short crust pastry: measure the flour into a large bowl and rub in the butter with your fingertips until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs (alternatively, this can be done in a food processor). Add about three tablespoons of cold water and mix to a firm dough, wrap in cling film and chill in the fridge for about 20 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6 and put a heavy baking tray in the oven to heat up. Grease a deep 18cm/7in loose-bottomed fluted flan tin with butter.
Remove about 150g/5½oz of pastry from the main ball and set aside for the lattice top.
Roll the rest of the pastry out thinly on a lightly floured work surface and line the prepared flan tin with the pastry.
Prick the base with a fork, to stop the base rising up during baking.
Place the reserved pastry for the lattice top on cling film and roll out thinly. Egg wash the pastry and set aside to chill in the fridge (the cling film makes it easier to move about). Do not cut into strips at this stage. Do not egg wash the strips once they are on the tart as it will drip into the treacle mixture.
To make the filling, heat the syrup gently in a large pan but do not boil.
Once melted, add the breadcrumbs, lemon juice and zest to the syrup. (You can add less lemon if you would prefer less citrus taste.) If the mixture looks runny, add a few more breadcrumbs.
Pour the syrup mixture into the lined tin and level the surface.
Remove the reserved pastry from the fridge and cut into long strips, 1cm/½in wide. Make sure they are all longer than the edges of the tart tin.
Egg wash the edge of the pastry in the tin, and start to make the woven laying lattice pattern over the mixture, leave the strips hanging over the edge of the tin.
Once the lattice is in place, use the tin edge to cut off the strips by pressing down with your hands, creating a neat finish.
Bake on the pre-heated baking tray in the hot oven for about 10 minutes until the pastry has started to colour, and then reduce the oven temperature to 180C/350F/Gas 4. If at this stage the lattice seems to be getting too dark brown, cover the tart with tin foil.
Bake for a further 25-30 minutes until the pastry is golden-brown and the filling set.
Remove the tart from the oven and leave to firm up in the tin. Serve warm or cold.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The primary ingredients in this recipe, such as butter, flour, and golden syrup, are high in fats and sugars, which can potentially slow metabolism rather than boost it. Lemon might have a slight benefit, but in negligible quantities defer to other qualities of the dessert.

boost_energy.explanation: While this dessert contains sugar and syrup that could provide a quick energy boost, the presence of high amounts of simple carbohydrates and fats might not offer sustained energy levels.

enhance_focus.explanation: There are no ingredients particularly known in TCM for enhancing focus. Lemon's slight invigorating nature is counterbalanced by the heavy and sweet consistency of the tart.

improve_immunity.explanation: Lemon contains vitamin C which can support immunity, but its impact is minimal when combined with the high sugar content which can adversely affect immune function.

improve_mobility.explanation: No specific ingredients in this recipe beneficially affect joint health or mobility from a TCM perspective. High sugar and fat content generally does not support joint health.

detox.explanation: Lemon is mildly detoxifying according to TCM, but its small amount compared to high sugar content does not make this recipe detoxifying.

enhance_mood.explanation: The comforting and rich qualities of the dessert can enhance mood temporarily. In TCM, sweetness can soothe the spirit, providing emotional comfort, though excess can imbalance.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: From a TCM perspective, the calming properties of sweetness can have a yin tonifying effect, which can be grounding and could support sleep quality by calming the spirit, offering a more restful night's sleep.

53074.strInstructions:
.  Prepare the eggplants for grilling by pricking them all over with a fork.  This is so it won’t burst during the grilling process as the natural water in it heats up.
2.  Grill the eggplants, turning them over frequently to ensure even cooking.  Grill until the skins are dark brown, even black and the eggplant is soft when you touch it.
3.  Soak the grilled eggplant in a bowl of water to cool it down.  Peel the skin off the eggplant.  Place the whole eggplants in a shallow dish (my mom actually cuts the eggplant into small, bite-sized pieces).
 4.  In a small mixing bowl, mix together the coconut milk or cream, lemon powder, salt and hot pepper.  Mix until the lemon powder and salt dissolve.  Taste, then adjust the amount of lemon powder, salt and hot pepper to your liking.  Pour the mixture over the eggplant.  Sprinkle the green onions over the eggplant and coconut milk.  Stir gently to combine.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of lemon juice may slightly aid in boosting metabolism, and hot pepper flakes can increase thermogenesis. However, these are present in relatively small quantities.

boost_energy.explanation: While coconut milk is energy-rich, the dish overall does not have many high-energy components as it's mostly composed of eggplant.

enhance_focus.explanation: No significant ingredients associated with cognitive enhancement are present in notable quantities.

improve_immunity.explanation: Eggplants, onions, and hot pepper flakes have properties that can contribute to overall immunity. The combination of these increases vitamin and antioxidant intake which supports immune function.

improve_mobility.explanation: Coconut milk can help with inflammation reduction to some extent, but lacks significant support for joint-specific ingredients.

detox.explanation: Eggplant, a primary ingredient, is known in TCM for its cooling and detoxifying properties, supporting liver health and cleansing the body. The addition of lemon juice enhances this property by aiding the digestive process and helping to cleanse toxins. Despite the small role of other ingredients, the abundance of eggplant as the main component of the dish makes detoxification the strongest potential benefit.

enhance_mood.explanation: Coconut milk adds a rich texture and taste that is generally comforting and mood-enhancing. However, this does not surpass its detox properties.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: No significant sleep-aiding ingredients present in the recipe that could contribute to improved sleep quality.

52876.strInstructions:
Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6.
Heat the oil in a deep frying pan and fry the beef mince for 4-5 minutes, breaking it up with a wooden spoon as it browns.
Add the onion and cook for 2-3 minutes, then stir in the tomato purée and cook for 2-3 more minutes. Stir in the flour and cook for a further minute, then add the chopped mushrooms, the stout or beef stock and a couple of dashes of Worcestershire sauce. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat, cover the pan with a lid and leave to simmer for 20 minutes. Set aside and leave to cool, then turn the meat mixture into a one litre pie dish.
Roll out the pastry on a floured work surface until it is slightly larger than the pie dish. Gently drape the pastry over the dish, pressing firmly onto the edges. Trim, then shape the edges into a fluted shape.
Cut some leaf shapes out of the pastry trimmings and decorate the top of the pie, sticking them to the pastry with the beaten egg yolk.
Make three or four slits in the pastry to allow the steam to escape, then brush the pie with the rest of the beaten egg yolk and bake in the oven for 20-25 minutes, or until golden-brown.
To serve, slice into wedges.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The minced beef and mushrooms provide proteins and B vitamins that can support metabolic processes, but the pie's richness in fats and carbohydrates from the pastry could slow digestion, offering moderate support for metabolism.

boost_energy.explanation: Minced beef is a rich source of iron and protein, essential for energy production. The beef stock and mushrooms also add minerals and vitamins that maintain energy levels. While the carbohydrates from pastry may offer immediate energy, the focus here is more on the sustaining energy provided by protein and nutrients.

enhance_focus.explanation: The protein and iron from beef might support focus by ensuring oxygen is efficiently transported to the brain, yet this dish does not prominently feature ingredients like nuts or fish, which are particularly beneficial for enhancing cognitive function.

improve_immunity.explanation: Mushrooms and onions are known to have immune-supportive properties. Mushrooms, in TCM, are believed to tonify the immune system. The overall warming nature of the dish can support the body's defensive Qi (immunity), though it's not as potent as herbs or foods specifically targeted for immunity.

improve_mobility.explanation: While proteins are essential for maintaining muscle health, this dish lacks specific ingredients like fish rich in omega-3s or specific herbs known to support joint lubrication and bone health.

detox.explanation: The dish primarily features meat and a rich pastry, which do not enhance detoxification processes in TCM. Instead, lighter and more bitter herbs or foods are traditionally used for detox.

enhance_mood.explanation: Nutrient-rich beef, in TCM, can bolster one's blood, which may affect mood due to better oxygenation and nutrient delivery to the brain. However, without specific mood-enhancing herbs such as licorice or ginger, the effect is moderate.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While this dish offers comfort, it isn't focused on relaxation or containing specific sleep-inducing foods, which in TCM would involve calming herbs or substances affecting the Heart and Shen (mind/spirit), such as jujube or lily bulb.

53022.strInstructions:
Add flour, eggs, milk, water, and salt in a large bowl then mix with a hand mixer until you have a smooth, lump-free batter.
At this point, mix in the butter or the vegetable oil. Alternatively, you can use them to grease the pan before frying each pancake.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat, then pour in the batter, swirling the pan to help it spread.
When the pancake starts pulling away a bit from the sides, and the top is no longer wet, flip it and cook shortly on the other side as well.
Transfer to a plate. Cook the remaining batter until all used up.
Serve warm, with the filling of your choice.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of butter and sugar lends some caloric density that might slightly enhance metabolism by creating a more thermogenic meal; however, the overall contribution to metabolism boost is minimal.

boost_energy.explanation: In TCM, eggs and milk are considered energy-strengthening ingredients. Eggs, being rich in protein, support yang energy, while milk nourishes yin and adds to the body's qi. The quick energy from sugar and the moderate amount of flour also contribute to a readily available energy source. These factors combined make this recipe somewhat energy-boosting.
