The finish: When the veal is fork-tender and falling away from the bone, remove the lid and sprinkle over half of the gremolata. Return the veal to the oven, uncovered, for another 15 minutes to caramelize it some.
Using a slotted spatula or spoon, carefully lift the shanks from the braising liquid, doing your best to keep them intact. The shanks will be very tender and threatening to fall into pieces, and the marrow will be wobbly inside the bones, so this can be a bit tricky. But if they do break apart, don’t worry, the flavor won’t suffer at all. Arrange the shanks on a serving platter or other large plate, without stacking, and cover with foil to keep warm.
Finishing the sauce: Set the braising pot on top of the stove and evaluate the sauce: if there is a visible layer of fat floating on the surface, use a large spoon to skim it off and discard it. Taste the sauce for concentration of flavor. If it tastes a bit weak or flat, bring it to a boil over high heat, and boil to reduce the volume and intensify the flavor for 5 to 10 minutes. Taste again for salt and pepper. If the sauce wants more zip, stir in a teaspoon or two of the remaining gremolata.
Portioning the veal shanks: if the shanks are reasonably sized, serve one per person. If the shanks are gargantuan or you’re dealing with modest appetites, pull apart the larger shanks, separating them at their natural seams, and serve smaller amounts. Be sure to give the marrow bones to whomever prizes them most.
Serving: Arrange the veal shanks on warm dinner plates accompanied by the risotto, if serving. Just before carrying the plates to the table, sprinkle on the remaining gremolata and then spoon over a generous amount of sauce – the contact with the hot liquid will aromatize the gremolata and perk up everyone’s appetite with the whiff of garlic and lemon.

boost_metabolism.explanation: While protein from veal can contribute to muscle repair and energy use efficiency, the overall dish is high in animal fat and calories, which might not optimally boost metabolism.

boost_energy.explanation: Veal provides a good source of protein and iron, essential for energy, while vegetables contribute vitamins and minerals. However, the rich preparation and slower digestion of braised meats may dilute this effect.

enhance_focus.explanation: The presence of fennel, which may improve memory and brain function, along with iron in veal promoting optimal brain oxygenation, contribute modestly to cognitive enhancement.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic, onions, and tomatoes provide immune-boosting properties due to antioxidants, but the high concentration of fats might counteract some of these benefits.

improve_mobility.explanation: Veal, rich in collagen and proteins, combined with the anti-inflammatory properties of ginger and garlic, can support joint health and inflammation control, enhancing mobility.

detox.explanation: The detoxifying properties of garlic and lemon zest are present but in small quantities. The dish's rich nature counterbalances significant detox benefits.

enhance_mood.explanation: While fennel and garlic could support serotonin regulation, the dish's heaviness may not inherently lift mood beyond enjoyable taste.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Although veal can be a source of tryptophan, the stimulating properties of garlic and citrus might counteract sleep aid potential.

52830.strInstructions:
Put the uncooked chicken breasts in the crock pot. Pour the full bottle of salad dressing over the chicken. Sprinkle the rest of the ingredients over the top and mix them in a bit with a spoon.
Cover your crock pot with the lid and cook on high for 4 hours.
Remove all the chicken breasts from the crock pot and let cool.
Shred the chicken breasts and move to a glass bowl.
Pour most of the liquid over the shredded chicken.
FOR THE TACOS:
Make the guacamole sauce by mixing the avocado and green salsa together. Pour the guacamole mixture through a strainer until smooth and transfer to a squeeze bottle. Cut the tip off the lid of the squeeze bottle to make the opening more wide if needed.
Make the sour cream sauce by mixing the sour cream and milk together until you get a more liquid sour cream sauce. Transfer to a squeeze bottle.
In a 9x 13 glass baking dish, fill all 12+ tacos with a layer of refried beans, cooked chicken and shredded cheese.
Bake at 450 for 10-15 minutes just until the cheese is melted and bubbling.
Out of the oven top all the tacos with the sliced grape tomaotes, jalapeno and cilantro.
Finish with a drizzle of guacamole and sour cream.
Enjoy!

boost_metabolism.explanation: The cumin and smoked paprika can enhance the metabolic rate to some extent, but their quantities are relatively small compared to the overall dish, reducing the metabolism-boosting impact.

boost_energy.explanation: Chicken is a high-protein ingredient that provides a steady supply of amino acids necessary for energy production. Refried beans also offer a good carbohydrate source, and the inclusion of avocado and cheese adds healthy fats to fuel energy. Together, these ingredients provide sustained energy release.

enhance_focus.explanation: Foods like avocado and cheese can contribute to cognitive function due to their fat content, which is essential for brain health. However, the dish doesn't primarily focus on ingredients known for cognitive enhancement.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic is well-known in TCM for its ability to strengthen the immune system. The inclusion of tomatoes and jalapenos also adds vitamin C, boosting immunity, but the overall impact is moderate due to the diversity of ingredients.

improve_mobility.explanation: While chicken provides protein that supports muscle health, there aren't significant ingredients in this dish specifically targeted for enhancing joint or bone health.

detox.explanation: Cumin and jalapenos possess some detoxifying properties, but the overall composition of the dish, being hearty and rich, does not prioritize detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: Avocado is rich in mood-enhancing nutrients like healthy fats, but the overall recipe is not focused on mood-enhancing benefits.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: There are no significant ingredients within this dish that are traditionally linked to aiding sleep quality within TCM.

52995.strInstructions:
1

Preheat oven to 450 degrees. Wash and dry all produce. Cut sweet potatoes into ½-inch-thick wedges. Toss on a baking sheet with a drizzle of oil, salt, and pepper. Roast until browned and tender, 20-25 minutes.

2

Meanwhile, halve and peel onion. Slice as thinly as possible until you have ¼ cup (½ cup for 4 servings); finely chop remaining onion. Peel and finely chop garlic. Halve lime; squeeze juice into a small bowl. Halve buns. Add 1 TBSP butter (2 TBSP for 4) to a separate small microwave-safe bowl; microwave until melted, 30 seconds. Brush onto cut sides of buns.

3

To bowl with lime juice, add sliced onion, ¼ tsp sugar (½ tsp for 4 servings), and a pinch of salt. Stir to combine; set aside to quick-pickle.

4

Heat a drizzle of oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Add chopped onion and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring, until softened, 4-5 minutes. Add garlic and cook until fragrant, 30 seconds more. Add pork and season with salt and pepper. Cook, breaking up meat into pieces, until browned and cooked through, 4-6 minutes.

5

While pork cooks, in a third small bowl, combine BBQ sauce, pickling liquid from onion, 3 TBSP ketchup (6 TBSP for 4 servings), ½ tsp sugar (1 tsp for 4), and ¼ cup water (⅓ cup for 4). Once pork is cooked through, add BBQ sauce mixture to pan. Cook, stirring, until sauce is thickened, 2-3 minutes. Taste and season with salt and pepper.

6

Meanwhile, toast buns in oven or toaster oven until golden, 3-5 minutes. Divide toasted buns between plates and fill with as much BBQ pork as you’d like. Top with pickled onion and hot sauce. Serve with sweet potato wedges on the side.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of ingredients like garlic and lime can support metabolic processes, but they are not in large quantities. Pork, though protein-rich, is more associated with providing energy rather than directly boosting metabolism from a TCM perspective.

boost_energy.explanation: This dish contains pork as a central ingredient, which is rich in protein and has yang qualities in TCM, which helps boost energy levels and vitality. The use of sweet potatoes adds complex carbohydrates, providing steady energy.

enhance_focus.explanation: Although garlic can promote mental clarity according to TCM, its effect in this dish is minimal due to its small quantity.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic and onions have immunity-boosting properties according to TCM, supporting lung and spleen functions. However, the pork dominates the recipe, diluting their effects.

improve_mobility.explanation: While pork is rich in collagen, beneficial for joint health, the focus on energy-boosting outweighs mobility benefits in this recipe.

detox.explanation: Lime has detoxifying properties in TCM, promoting liver function, but the overall dish does not strongly support detox.

enhance_mood.explanation: The yang energy from pork and the presence of sweet flavors can contribute to mood enhancement, but this benefit is secondary.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The ingredients used are not typically associated with enhancing sleep in TCM, as the recipe is more invigorating.

53059.strInstructions: Chop the onion and garlic, slice the mushrooms and wash the buckwheat. Heat the oil and lightly sauté the onion. Add the mushrooms and the garlic and continue to sauté. Add the salt, vegetable seasoning, buckwheat and the bay leaf and cover with water. Simmer gently and just before it is completely cooked, add pepper, sour cream mixed with flour, the chopped parsley and vinegar to taste.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The use of garlic can have a mild effect on metabolism as it is known to help regulate blood sugar and thus indirectly influences metabolic functions. However, its presence is not dominant enough to strongly influence this meal’s overall metabolic boosting capability.

boost_energy.explanation: Buckwheat provides a good source of carbohydrates and essential amino acids that help sustain energy levels, coupled with the energizing properties of mushrooms. However, the energy boost is moderate due to the absence of any potent yang-strengthening foods.

enhance_focus.explanation: The inclusion of mushrooms, particularly if they are varieties like shiitake, can support brain health and cognitive functions through their nutrient profile. However, ingredients that are typically considered nootropic in TCM are not prominent here.

improve_immunity.explanation: This soup is rich in immune-boosting ingredients. Garlic is well-known in TCM for its antibacterial and antiviral properties, which help expel toxins and move Qi, thus protecting the body from pathogens. Mushrooms, specifically known varieties like shiitake or maitake, can enhance immune function due to their beta-glucans, while bay leaves and parsley additionally provide essential vitamins and minerals that enhance the body's resistance against illnesses.

improve_mobility.explanation: There is limited influence on joint health with the present ingredients. While buckwheat is nutritious, its impact on mobility, in terms of joint health, isn't substantial.

detox.explanation: Parsley and garlic can aid detoxification due to their diuretic and antibacterial properties. Vinegar can also have cleansing benefits to the digestive system. However, the meal’s overall detoxifying effect is mild.

enhance_mood.explanation: Garlic and onion are known to move stagnant Qi, which can lift the mood, but the effect is gentle. This recipe lacks potent mood-enhancing ingredients such as those high in tryptophan or adaptogenic herbs used in TCM.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While the soup is warm and comforting, which can be soothing, it lacks direct sedative ingredients like certain herbs that enhance sleep quality directly.

52946.strInstructions:
Mix the cornflour and 1 tbsp soy sauce, toss in the prawns and set aside for 10 mins. Stir the vinegar, remaining soy sauce, tomato purée, sugar and 2 tbsp water together to make a sauce.

When you’re ready to cook, heat a large frying pan or wok until very hot, then add 1 tbsp oil. Fry the prawns until they are golden in places and have opened out– then tip them out of the pan.

Heat the remaining oil and add the peanuts, chillies and water chestnuts. Stir-fry for 2 mins or until the peanuts start to colour, then add the ginger and garlic and fry for 1 more min. Tip in the prawns and sauce and simmer for 2 mins until thickened slightly. Serve with rice.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The dish contains ginger, which is known for its metabolism-boosting properties in TCM. However, the overall influence is mild due to the presence of sugar and oil that might counteract this effect.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of prawns, peanuts, and water chestnuts provides a good balance of protein, healthy fats, and carbohydrates, offering sustained energy levels. However, the presence of sugar slightly reduces its potential as a primary energy-boosting dish.

enhance_focus.explanation: Ginger and garlic are known for promoting mental clarity in TCM, enhancing focus and brain function. The presence is not overly significant in this dish to make it a primary benefit.

improve_immunity.explanation: Prawns and garlic are potent ingredients in TCM for improving immunity. Prawns replenish essential nutrients, while garlic is well-known for its antibacterial properties. The combination with ginger further strengthens the immune system. This makes it the primary health benefit.

improve_mobility.explanation: While prawns provide beneficial nutrients for joint health, the dish does not focus significantly on ingredients traditionally used to improve mobility, such as bones or connective tissues.

detox.explanation: Ginger and garlic contribute mildly to detoxification, but the overall dish does not emphasize detox ingredients like leafy greens or herbs prominently.

enhance_mood.explanation: Chili and garlic can help elevate mood by increasing circulation and promoting a sense of warmth. Their mood-enhancing effects are secondary to the dish's immune-boosting properties.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish is not particularly high in calming ingredients typically associated with aiding sleep quality, such as chamomile or other soothing herbs.

53055.strInstructions:
Place the ground meat in a bowl. Chop the onion very finely and grate the garlic cloves. Add to the bowl. Add the chopped parsley, all sorts of paprika, baking soda, dried breadcrumbs, water, Vegeta, salt, and pepper.
Mix well with the hand mixer fitted with the dough hooks. Cover the bowl with cling film/ plastic foil and leave to rest for 1 or 2 hours in the refrigerator.
Take portions of the meat mixture, about 50-55 g/ 1.7-1.9 oz/ ¼ cup portions, and form the cevapi. The rolls should be about as thick as your thumb and about 7-10 cm/ 3-4 inches long. I had 18 sausages. The recipe can be easily doubled.
Grill the cevapcici on the hot grill pan or on the barbecue for about 12-14 minutes, turning them several times in between, or until brown and cooked through. I checked by cutting one in the middle and then grilling the following batches for the same period of time.
Serve hot as suggested above. The cevapcici can be reheated in the oven at 180 degrees Celsius/ 350 degrees Fahrenheit for about 10 minutes or until heated through. Check one, if it is not hot enough, give the sausages a few more minutes.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of garlic and paprika can enhance warming properties and stimulate qi, potentially supporting metabolism. However, the dish is not focused on metabolism-boosting as its primary purpose.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of beef and pork provides high protein and fat content, enhancing Qi and energy according to TCM. Beef promotes yang energy, which is invigorating. The recipe's cooking method and its filling nature can help sustain energy levels throughout the day.

enhance_focus.explanation: Garlic and parsley might offer slight benefits in improving mental focus due to their ability to enhance circulation and provide antioxidants, but they are not in predominant amounts to make this the main focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic is known for its immune-boosting properties in TCM, and its significant quantity supports this benefit. However, it is not the main focus of the dish.

improve_mobility.explanation: The high protein content can contribute to muscle and joint support, but the recipe does not specifically target mobility-enhancing ingredients in sufficient quantities.

52812.strInstructions:
1 Prepare the brisket for cooking: On one side of the brisket there should be a layer of fat, which you want. If there are any large chunks of fat, cut them off and discard them. Large pieces of fat will not be able to render out completely.
Using a sharp knife, score the fat in parallel lines, about 3/4-inch apart. Slice through the fat, not the beef. Repeat in the opposite direction to make a cross-hatch pattern.
Salt the brisket well and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.
 
2 Sear the brisket: You'll need an oven-proof, thick-bottomed pot with a cover, or Dutch oven, that is just wide enough to hold the brisket roast with a little room for the onions.
Pat the brisket dry and place it, fatty side down, into the pot and place it on medium high heat. Cook for 5-8 minutes, lightly sizzling, until the fat side is nicely browned. (If the roast seems to be cooking too fast, turn the heat down to medium. You want a steady sizzle, not a raging sear.)
Turn the brisket over and cook for a few minutes more to brown the other side.

3 Sauté the onions and garlic: When the brisket has browned, remove it from the pot and set aside. There should be a couple tablespoons of fat rendered in the pot, if not, add some olive oil.
Add the chopped onions and increase the heat to high. Sprinkle a little salt on the onions. Sauté, stirring often, until the onions are lightly browned, 5-8 minutes. Stir in the garlic and cook 1-2 more minutes.
 
4 Return brisket to pot, add herbs, stock, bring to simmer, cover, cook in oven: Preheat the oven to 300°F. Use kitchen twine to tie together the bay leaves, rosemary and thyme.
Move the onions and garlic to the sides of the pot and nestle the brisket inside. Add the beef stock and the tied-up herbs. Bring the stock to a boil on the stovetop.
Cover the pot, place the pot in the 300°F oven and cook for 3 hours. Carefully flip the brisket every hour so it cooks evenly.
 
5 Add carrots, continue to cook: After 3 hours, add the carrots. Cover the pot and cook for 1 hour more, or until the carrots are cooked through and the brisket is falling-apart tender.
6 Remove brisket to cutting board, tent with foil: When the brisket is falling-apart tender, take the pot out of the oven and remove the brisket to a cutting board. Cover it with foil. Pull out and discard the herbs.
7 Make sauce (optional): At this point you have two options. You can serve as is, or you can make a sauce with the drippings and some of the onions. If you serve as is, skip this step.
To make a sauce, remove the carrots and half of the onions, set aside and cover them with foil. Pour the ingredients that are remaining into the pot into a blender, and purée until smooth. If you want, add 1 tablespoon of mustard to the mix. Put into a small pot and keep warm.
8 Slice the meat across the grain: Notice the lines of the muscle fibers of the roast. This is the "grain" of the meat. Slice the meat perpendicular to these lines, or across the grain (cutting this way further tenderizes the meat), in 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch slices.
Serve with the onions, carrots and gravy. Serve with mashed, roasted or boiled potatoes, egg noodles or polenta.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The recipe includes garlic, which in TCM is known to stimulate digestion and increase circulation, potentially supporting metabolic function. However, its effect is moderate, and the overall impact on metabolism from this recipe is not as strong due to the high focus on meat and heavier ingredients.

52779.strInstructions: Crust: make a dough from 250g flour (I like mixing different flours like plain and wholegrain spelt flour), 125g butter, 1 egg and a pinch of salt, press it into a tart form and place it in the fridge. Filling: stir 300g cream cheese and 100ml milk until smooth, add in 3 eggs, 100g grated parmesan cheese and season with salt, pepper and nutmeg. Take the crust out of the fridge and prick the bottom with a fork. Pour in the filling and bake at 175 degrees C for about 25 minutes. Cover the tart with some aluminium foil after half the time. In the mean time, slice about 350g mini tomatoes. In a small pan heat 3tbsp olive oil, 3tbsp white vinegar, 1 tbsp honey, salt and pepper and combine well. Pour over the tomato slices and mix well. With a spoon, place the tomato slices on the tart, avoiding too much liquid on it. Decorate with basil leaves and enjoy

boost_metabolism.explanation: Certain ingredients like vinegar and tomatoes have a cooling nature that could slightly enhance metabolic functions, but the dish as a whole is heavy on fats and dairy, which does not optimally boost metabolism according to TCM.

boost_energy.explanation: Eggs and cream cheese are energy-rich ingredients that can enhance qi. However, the high fat content might dampen the energy-boosting potential slightly.

improve_immunity.explanation: Tomatoes contain vitamin C, and the presence of basil provides some support for the liver and respiratory systems, indirectly aiding immunity. However, influences are mild compared to more potent TCM herbs known for boosting immunity.

52815.strMeal: French Lentils With Garlic and Thyme
52815.strInstructions:
Place a large saucepan over medium heat and add oil. When hot, add chopped vegetables and sauté until softened, 5 to 10 minutes.
Add 6 cups water, lentils, thyme, bay leaves and salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a fast simmer.
Simmer lentils until they are tender and have absorbed most of the water, 20 to 25 minutes. If necessary, drain any excess water after lentils have cooked. Serve immediately, or allow them to cool and reheat later.
For a fuller taste, use some chicken stock and reduce the water by the same amount.

1.	Add beef. Saute until the outer part turns light brown.

3.	Add Knorr Beef Cube. Cover the pressure cooker. Cook for 30 minutes.
4.	Pan-fry carrot and potato until it browns. Set aside.
5.	Add chili pepper, liver spread and peanut butter. Stir.
6.	Add bell peppers, fried potato and carrot. Cover the pot. Continue cooking for 5 to 7 minutes.
7.	Season with salt and ground black pepper. Serve.

53015.strInstructions:
Dissolve yeast in warm water in 2 1/2-quart bowl. Add milk, sugar, salt, eggs, shortening and 2 cups flour. Beat on low for 30 seconds, scraping bowl constantly. Beat on medium speed for 2 minutes, scraping bowl occasionally. Stir in remaining flour until smooth. Cover and let rise until double, 50-60 minutes. (Dough is ready when indentation remains when touched.) Turn dough onto floured surface; roll around lightly to coat with flour. Gently roll dough 1/2-inch thick with floured rolling pin. Cut with floured doughnut cutter. Cover and let rise until double, 30-40 minutes.
Heat vegetable oil in deep fryer to 350°. Slide doughnuts into hot oil with wide spatula. Turn doughnuts as they rise to the surface. Fry until golden brown, about 1 minute on each side. Remove carefully from oil (do not prick surface); drain. Dip the doughnuts into creamy glaze set on rack.


Glaze: 
Heat butter until melted. Remove from heat. Stir in powdered sugar and vanilla until smooth. Stir in water, 1 tablespoon at a time, until desired consistency.

53032.strInstructions:
STEP 1
Remove the large piece of fat on the edge of each pork loin, then bash each of the loins between two pieces of baking parchment until around 1cm in thickness – you can do this using a meat tenderiser or a rolling pin. Once bashed, use your hands to reshape the meat to its original shape and thickness – this step will ensure the meat is as succulent as possible.

STEP 2
Put the flour, eggs and panko breadcrumbs into three separate wide-rimmed bowls. Season the meat, then dip first in the flour, followed by the eggs, then the breadcrumbs.

STEP 3
In a large frying or sauté pan, add enough oil to come 2cm up the side of the pan. Heat the oil to 180C – if you don’t have a thermometer, drop a bit of panko into the oil and if it sinks a little then starts to fry, the oil is ready. Add two pork chops and cook for 1 min 30 secs on each side, then remove and leave to rest on a wire rack for 5 mins. Repeat with the remaining pork chops.

STEP 4
While the pork is resting, make the sauce by whisking the ingredients together, adding a splash of water if it’s particularly thick. Slice the tonkatsu and serve drizzled with the sauce.

The presence of eggs further contributes to protein intake. The energy-rich oils also add caloric content, supporting immediate energy needs. Additionally, the balanced measure of sauce ingredients adds calories, which serve as a quick energy source. From a TCM standpoint, pork is thought to nourish Qi (energy) and support yang, which can help combat fatigue and improve vitality.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: There are no specific calming or sedative ingredients present, which are known in TCM to improve sleep quality, such as jujube or chamomile.

53045.strInstructions:
STEP 1

Heat a drizzle of oil in a large, deep-sided frying pan, and fry the onion and pepper on a medium heat until softened but not browned. Finely chop the coriander stalks (keep the leaves for later), and add to the pan with the chilli and chopped garlic. Fry for another few minutes. Add the wine, saffron and bay leaf and let it simmer until reduced by half.

STEP 2

Add the potatoes, tomatoes, and 300ml water and bring to a gentle boil. Break up the tomatoes with a spoon on the side of the pan and simmer for 20-25 minutes until the potatoes are just tender, and the tomatoes have broken down.

STEP 3

Season well, then gently push the fish into the sauce, and arrange the squid, prawns, clams and mussels on the surface. Put the lid on and cook for 6-8 minutes until the mussel and clam shells have opened, the prawns are cooked and the fish is flaky. Toast the bread, rub lightly with the halved garlic clove and drizzle with olive oil. Serve the stew scatted with chopped coriander leaves, and the toasts for dunking.

boost_energy.explanation: This fish stew is rich in protein from cod, squid, prawns, clams, and mussels, providing sustained energy. The carbohydrates from potatoes further support energy levels. In Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), seafood is known to nourish the body's Qi, helping to enhance vitality. The presence of saffron and garlic complements this by invigorating the blood and circulatory system, thus contributing to an overall boost in energy.

enhance_focus.explanation: The presence of Omega-3 fatty acids in seafood can potentially enhance cognitive functions, contributing to better focus. However, the quantities and nature of the dish are not primarily designed for cognitive enhancement.

52895.strInstructions:
Heat the flat grill plate over a low heat, on top of 2 rings/flames if it fits, and brush sparingly with light olive oil.
Cook the sausages first. Add the sausages to the hot grill plate/the coolest part if there is one and allow to cook slowly for about 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally, until golden. After the first 10 minutes, increase the heat to medium before beginning to cook the other ingredients. If you are struggling for space, completely cook the sausages and keep hot on a plate in the oven.
Snip a few small cuts into the fatty edge of the bacon. Place the bacon straight on to the grill plate and fry for 2-4 minutes each side or until your preferred crispiness is reached. Like the sausages, the cooked bacon can be kept hot on a plate in the oven.
For the mushrooms, brush away any dirt using a pastry brush and trim the stalk level with the mushroom top. Season with salt and pepper and drizzle over a little olive oil. Place stalk-side up on the grill plate and cook for 1-2 minutes before turning and cooking for a further 3-4 minutes. Avoid moving the mushrooms too much while cooking, as this releases the natural juices, making them soggy.
For the tomatoes, cut the tomatoes across the centre/or in half lengthways if using plum tomatoes , and with a small, sharp knife remove the green 'eye'. Season with salt and pepper and drizzle with a little olive oil. Place cut-side down on the grill plate and cook without moving for 2 minutes. Gently turn over and season again. Cook for a further 2-3 minutes until tender but still holding their shape.
For the black pudding, cut the black pudding into 3-4 slices and remove the skin. Place on the grill plate and cook for 1½-2 minutes each side until slightly crispy.
For 'proper' fried bread it's best to cook it in a separate pan. Ideally, use bread that is a couple of days old. Heat a frying pan to a medium heat and cover the base with oil. Add the bread and cook for 2-3 minutes each side until crispy and golden. If the pan becomes too dry, add a little more oil. For a richer flavour, add a knob of butter after you turn the slice.
For the fried eggs, break the egg straight into the pan with the fried bread and leave for 30 seconds. Add a good knob of butter and lightly splash/baste the egg with the butter when melted. Cook to your preferred stage, season and gently remove with a fish slice.
Once all the ingredients are cooked, serve on warm plates and enjoy straight away with a good squeeze of tomato ketchup or brown sauce.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of protein-rich ingredients such as sausages, bacon, and eggs can moderately support metabolism. However, this is counterbalanced by the presence of high-fat content, which in TCM may contribute to accumulation and impede metabolic processes.

boost_energy.explanation: This dish contains a high protein and fat content from sausages, bacon, and eggs, providing substantial energy for physical and mental activity. In TCM, meats are considered warming and yang-supporting, which invigorates qi, boosting overall energy levels. This protein and fat-rich breakfast provides a significant caloric intake, which is beneficial in revitalizing and preventing fatigue throughout the day.

enhance_focus.explanation: Eggs and mushrooms are beneficial for enhancing cognitive function to a degree, but the dish’s overall heavy and greasy nature might be counterproductive to maintaining long-lasting mental clarity.

improve_immunity.explanation: Eggs and tomatoes can contribute to strengthening the body's Wei Qi (defensive Qi), due to their nutritious profiles that support general health. However, the dish is not predominantly focused on ingredients known for their immune-boosting properties in TCM.

improve_mobility.explanation: There is limited support for joint flexibility and bone health, as the meal lacks ingredients that are specifically beneficial for enhancing joint health or mobility in TCM.

detox.explanation: The presence of tomatoes and mushrooms can offer slight detoxifying effects, aligning with TCM’s view that these ingredients help facilitate the flow of Qi and blood. Nonetheless, greasy and heavy components, like sausages and bacon, might counteract these benefits.

52951.strInstructions:
DIRECTIONS:
STEP 1 - SAUCE
In a bowl, add 2 Cups of water, 2 Tablespoon soy sauce, 2 Tablespoon white vinegar, sherry cooking wine, 1/4 Teaspoon white pepper, minced ginger, minced garlic, hot pepper, ketchup, hoisin sauce, and sugar.
Mix together well and set aside.
STEP 2 - MARINATING THE CHICKEN
In a bowl, add the chicken, 1 pinch of salt, 1 pinch of white pepper, 2 egg whites, and 3 Tablespoon of corn starch
STEP 3 - DEEP FRY THE CHICKEN
Deep fry the chicken at 350 degrees for 3-4 minutes or until it is golden brown and loosen up the chicken so that they don't stick together.
Set the chicken aside.
STEP 4 - STIR FRY
Add the sauce to the wok and then the broccoli and wait until it is boiling.
To thicken the sauce, whisk together 2 Tablespoon of cornstarch and 4 Tablespoon of water in a bowl and slowly add to your stir-fry until it's the right thickness.
Next add in the chicken and stir-fry for a minute and serve on a plate

boost_metabolism.explanation: The dish incorporates chicken, which is high in protein. Protein can slightly enhance metabolism due to its thermic effect; however, the deep-frying and sugary sauce may offset metabolic benefits.

boost_energy.explanation: This dish includes chicken, which is a significant source of protein, vital for energy and strength in TCM. Moreover, ginger and garlic can enhance digestive fire, thereby improving energy levels. However, frying and the sauce’s sugar content may lead to energy dips.

enhance_focus.explanation: The ginger and garlic could potentially support mental clarity according to TCM, but they are not in quantities large enough to significantly impact focus.

153050.strInstructions:
1. Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium heat.
2. Add the ginger and garlic, and sauté for about 2 minutes until fragrant.
3. Add the beef shank chunks and brown on all sides.
4. Pour in the beef bone broth and bring to a boil.
5. Add the turmeric powder, carrots, celery, and sweet potatoes, and simmer for about 1 hour until the beef is tender.
6. Add the salmon chunks and kale, and cook for an additional 10-15 minutes until the salmon is cooked through and the kale is wilted.
7. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
8. Garnish with fresh herbs before serving.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Garlic and ginger slightly boost metabolism, but not significantly in the overall context of the recipe, which is rich and hearty.

boost_energy.explanation: The stew contains energy-supportive ingredients like turmeric, sweet potatoes, and salmon, which provide sustained energy release, making it moderately beneficial for energy enhancement.

enhance_focus.explanation: While turmeric and ginger can support cognitive function, their concentrations in this recipe are relatively low compared to ingredients like bone broth, which do not directly enhance focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: The presence of bone broth, garlic, and ginger contributes to immunity support, as these ingredients are known for their immune-strengthening properties.

improve_mobility.explanation: The combination of beef bone broth, turmeric, ginger, and omega-3 rich salmon collectively supports joint and bone health, providing nourishment to enhance mobility. Bone broth supplies nutrients like collagen and glucosamine, essential for joint health, while turmeric and ginger possess anti-inflammatory properties that may alleviate joint discomfort. Salmon, rich in omega-3 fatty acids, further supports joint lubrication and flexibility, making this stew particularly potent for improving overall mobility.

enhance_mood.explanation: The presence of omega-3 fatty acids in salmon can contribute to mood enhancement slightly, but it is not the primary focus here.

52915.strInstructions:
Get everything ready. Warm a 20cm (measured across the top) non-stick frying pan on a medium heat. Crack the eggs into a bowl and beat them with a fork so they break up and mix, but not as completely as you would for scrambled egg. With the heat on medium-hot, drop one knob of butter into the pan. It should bubble and sizzle, but not brown. Season the eggs with the Parmesan and a little salt and pepper, and pour into the pan.
Let the eggs bubble slightly for a couple of seconds, then take a wooden fork or spatula and gently draw the mixture in from the sides of the pan a few times, so it gathers in folds in the centre. Leave for a few seconds, then stir again to lightly combine uncooked egg with cooked. Leave briefly again, and when partly cooked, stir a bit faster, stopping while there’s some barely cooked egg left. With the pan flat on the heat, shake it back and forth a few times to settle the mixture. It should slide easily in the pan and look soft and moist on top. A quick burst of heat will brown the underside.
Grip the handle underneath. Tilt the pan down away from you and let the omelette fall to the edge. Fold the side nearest to you over by a third with your fork, and keep it rolling over, so the omelette tips onto a plate – or fold it in half, if that’s easier. For a neat finish, cover the omelette with a piece of kitchen paper and plump it up a bit with your fingers. Rub the other knob of butter over to glaze. Serve immediately.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of eggs provides a good source of protein and fats, which can aid in sustaining energy levels and supporting a healthy metabolism. However, high-fat content, such as from butter and cheese, might not specifically target metabolism-boosting due to the low metabolism-stimulating herb usage.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of eggs and Gruyère cheese, rich in protein and fats, supports energy sustenance. Eggs are often recommended in TCM for strengthening Qi (vital energy), enhancing overall vitality, and combating fatigue. Herbs like tarragon and chives add to the dish's fresh nature and contribute to moderate Yang energy, supporting vitality.

enhance_focus.explanation: Herbs like parsley and chives have a mild effect on mental clarity, but their relative quantity is minimal compared to the protein and fat-rich nature of the dish. The major energy components are in support of physical rather than mental activity.

improve_immunity.explanation: While eggs and herbs introduce some immune-supporting nutrients, the absence of prominent ingredients known for powerful immune-boosting properties, such as garlic or ginger, restricts this benefit. However, the protein in eggs provides general support to the body's defenses.

improve_mobility.explanation: The dish offers moderate support with protein contributing to muscle health, yet lacks substantial amounts of components like bones or cartilage-focused ingredients that directly support joint health in TCM.

detox.explanation: This is not a primary focus of the dish. While some herbs have cleansing properties, their presence is not strong enough to warrant a high score in supporting detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: Eggs and dairy support serotonin production and overall mood enhancement. Herbs contribute mildly to emotional well-being through pleasant flavors. The comforting nature of the dish can uplift mood, but this is a secondary impact relative to energy boosting.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Dairy products and the soothing nature of herbs can have a mild effect on promoting relaxation but are not actively inducing sleep. The presence of energy-boosting elements like eggs contrasts the idea of aiding sleep quality directly.

53054.strInstructions:
Soak glutinous rice with water for at least 1 ½ hours prior to using. Drain.
Prepare a 9-inch round or square cake pan and spray with cooking spray or line with plastic wrap.
Mix coconut milk, water, salt and the rice. Pour it into cake pan, topped with the pandan knots.
Steam for 30 minutes.
After 30 minutes, fluff up the rice and remove pandan knots. Then, using a greased spatula, flatten the steamed rice. Make sure there are no holes/air bubbles and gaps in the rice, especially the sides.
Steam for another 10 minutes.

Combine pandan juice, coconut milk, all purpose flour, cornflour, and sugar. Mix well.
Add eggs and whisk well then strain into a medium sized metal bowl or pot.
Place pandan mixture over simmering water (double boiler or bain-marie)
Stir continuously and cook till custard starts to thicken. (15 minutes)
Pour pandan custard into glutinous rice layer, give it a little tap (for air bubbles) and continue to steam for 30 minutes.
Remove kuih seri muka from the steamer and allow to cool completely before cutting into rectangles or diamond shapes.

boost_metabolism.explanation: While glutinous rice is rich in carbohydrates, it's not particularly known for enhancing metabolism in TCM. However, the dish is not heavily spiced or fermented to significantly boost metabolic rate.

boost_energy.explanation: The primary ingredients like glutinous rice and coconut milk are rich in carbohydrates, which provide a good source of sustained energy. From a TCM standpoint, rice is often used to strengthen the spleen and boost Qi (energy), making it effective for combating fatigue. The inclusion of eggs adds protein and further supports overall energy levels.

enhance_focus.explanation: Although there is no ingredient specifically known for enhancing focus, the balanced blend of carbohydrates and protein may offer some support for sustained mental energy, albeit not significantly.

improve_immunity.explanation: Coconut milk contains lauric acid which may support immune function, and eggs provide essential amino acids. However, this dish is not primarily composed of immune-boosting ingredients like medicinal herbs or mushrooms.

improve_mobility.explanation: There are no specific ingredients in this dessert that are traditionally used in TCM to support joint or bone health.

detox.explanation: The pandan leaves used for flavoring might offer mild detoxifying properties, yet they are present more for aroma than substantial health impacts.

enhance_mood.explanation: Sweet dishes can offer a mood lift through flavor. From a TCM perspective, sweets in moderation can console the heart. However, this is more about temporary satisfaction rather than a profound mood-enhancing effect.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: There are no prominent calming or sleep-inducing ingredients, such as those that would nourish the heart or calm the mind, in the recipe.

52980.strInstructions:
Wash and peel the potatoes and cut into similarly sized pieces for even cooking.

In a large soup pot, boil the potatoes and the bay leaves in salted water for 20 minutes. Discard the bay leaves.

If you're not using a bag of ready-cut curly kale, wash the bunches thoroughly under cool running water to get rid of all soil—you wouldn't want that gritty texture in your finished dish. Trim any coarse stems and discard any brown leaves. With a sharp knife, cut the curly kale into thin strips.

Peel and chop the shallots.

In a frying pan or skillet, melt 1 tbsp. of butter and saute the shallots for a few minutes before adding the curly kale and 2 tbsp. of water. Season and cook for about 10 minutes, or until tender.

Warm the milk on the stove or in the microwave.

Drain, shake and dry the potatoes with kitchen towels before mashing with a potato masher or ricer. Working quickly, add the warm milk and the remaining butter. Season to taste with nutmeg, salt, and pepper. 

Mix the cooked curly kale through the cooked mashed potato mixture.

Top with slices of the smoked sausage and serve hot with your favorite mustard or gravy.

Serve and enjoy!

boost_metabolism.explanation: This dish includes spices like nutmeg, which can slightly stimulate metabolism according to TCM. However, the presence of heavy ingredients such as potatoes and butter, which are more nourishing than metabolically stimulating, reduces its impact on metabolism boost.

boost_energy.explanation: Potatoes are a great source of carbohydrates, essential for energy provision in TCM. The addition of kale provides iron, and vitamin C supports qì (energy) flow and helps combat fatigue. Sausages add protein, further sustaining energy levels.

enhance_focus.explanation: The shallots have slight cognitive-enhancing qualities, and kale is nutrient-dense. However, the overall dish is more weighted towards nourishment rather than cognitive enhancement, giving it a moderate score.

improve_immunity.explanation: Kale is rich in vitamins A, C, and K, all crucial for immune support, fitting TCM's perspective on fortifying the body's defenses. Shallots also contain compounds that can enhance immunity, but their quantity is minimal here.

improve_mobility.explanation: While kale provides vitamin K for bone health, the dish overall lacks significant support for joint flexibility or mobility-enhancing components such as invigorating spices or herbs.

detox.explanation: Kale offers some detoxifying benefits due to its high fiber content, though the dish as a whole, which includes sausages and butter, is not particularly focused on detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: The warmth of the potatoes and the use of nutmeg may bring some comfort and slight mood elevation according to TCM. However, mood enhancement is not primary here.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While milk can be calming, the dish is high in fat and protein, which might not be conducive to relaxation and sleep quality. Thus, it scores low in aiding sleep.

52804.strInstructions:
Heat oil in a deep fryer or deep heavy skillet to 365°F (185°C).
Warm gravy in saucepan or microwave.
Place the fries into the hot oil, and cook until light brown, about 5 minutes.
Remove to a paper towel lined plate to drain.
Place the fries on a serving platter, and sprinkle the cheese over them.
Ladle gravy over the fries and cheese, and serve immediately.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The dish is rich in fats from vegetable oil and cheese curds, which could potentially burden the digestive system rather than boost metabolism. It lacks the presence of metabolism-boosting ingredients often emphasized in TCM, such as green tea or ginger.

boost_energy.explanation: The high carbohydrate content from potatoes offers a quick source of energy, supporting vitality, but the heavy fat content may lead to sluggishness if consumed excessively.

enhance_focus.explanation: There are no specific ingredients in this recipe that are revered in TCM for enhancing cognitive functions, such as walnuts or goji berries.

improve_immunity.explanation: While the warmth of the beef gravy might contribute slightly to enhancing the 'Yang' energy according to TCM, there are no significant ingredients focused on boosting the immune system.

improve_mobility.explanation: The recipe lacks ingredients known in TCM for promoting joint health or reducing inflammation, such as ginger or turmeric.

detox.explanation: The heavy use of fats and dairy could potentially burden the body rather than support detoxification. There are no detoxifying herbs or vegetables included.

enhance_mood.explanation: The combination of warm, comforting ingredients like potatoes, cheese, and gravy can act as a mood enhancer in TCM due to their calming and satisfying nature. The rich flavors may provide emotional comfort, reducing stress momentarily and elevating mood.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The heavy, rich nature of the dish might make it too dense to consume before bedtime, potentially hindering sleep rather than aiding it, according to TCM principles on digestion and rest.

52979.strInstructions:
Melt the butter in a skillet or pan. When melted, add the flour little by little and stir into a thick paste. Slowly stir in the stock, making sure the roux absorbs the liquid. Simmer for a couple of minutes on a low heat while you stir in the onion, parsley and the shredded meat. The mixture should thicken and turn into a heavy, thick sauce.

Pour the mixture into a shallow container, cover and refrigerate for several hours, or until the sauce has solidified.

Take a heaping tablespoon of the cold, thick sauce and quickly roll it into a small ball. Roll lightly through the flour, then the egg and finally the breadcrumbs. Make sure that the egg covers the whole surface of the bitterbal. When done, refrigerate the snacks while the oil in your fryer heats up to 190C (375F). Fry four bitterballen at a time, until golden.

Serve on a plate with a nice grainy or spicy mustard.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of beef, which is high in protein, can contribute to boosting metabolism slightly by increasing the thermic effect of food. However, the recipe is high in fats from butter and overall caloric content, which doesn't precisely optimize for metabolism.

boost_energy.explanation: The high protein content from beef and nutritional value from beef stock provide a substantial energy boost. Beef is considered yang in TCM, which can invigorate and strengthen the body's vital energies, providing a solid foundation for energy. Moreover, eggs also contribute to vitality.

enhance_focus.explanation: While beef contains iron, which supports mental alertness, the meal's richness in fats might lead to sluggishness if consumed in large amounts, limiting its effectiveness in enhancing focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Onion and parsley offer some antibacterial properties, and beef provides zinc, which is beneficial for immunity, but these are not sufficient in quantity to significantly boost immunity.

improve_mobility.explanation: The dish lacks significant amounts of ingredients traditionally used in TCM to improve joint or bone health; hence, it doesn't strongly promote mobility.

detox.explanation: There are no specific detoxifying elements in the recipe, as it mostly includes richer, heavier ingredients like beef and butter, which are not typically associated with detoxification in TCM.

enhance_mood.explanation: Nutmeg is known for its soothing properties and can enhance mood slightly, and the comforting aspect of the savory dish could be mood-enhancing, though not profoundly.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish contains nutmeg, known for its potential to promote relaxation and improve sleep, but in very minimal amounts; the heavier meat content might interfere with sleep for some individuals.

52960.strInstructions:
Season the salmon, then rub with oil. Mix the dressing ingredients together. Halve, stone, peel and slice the avocados. Halve and quarter the cucumber lengthways, then cut into slices. Divide salad, avocado and cucumber between four plates, then drizzle with half the dressing.

Heat a non-stick pan. Add the salmon and fry for 3-4 mins on each side until crisp but still moist inside. Put a salmon fillet on top of each salad and drizzle over the remaining dressing. Serve warm.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The presence of salmon and avocado provides omega-3 fatty acids and healthy fats, which can help regulate metabolism and support weight management. The inclusion of lime and honey in the dressing also contributes to increasing metabolic rates slightly.

boost_energy.explanation: Salmon is a rich source of high-quality protein and omega-3 fatty acids, which are excellent for providing sustained energy. Avocado adds healthy fats, further enhancing energy levels by providing a steady release due to its slow digestion. Cucumber and spinach contribute water and micronutrients to maintain hydration and overall vitality.

enhance_focus.explanation: Omega-3 fatty acids from salmon can aid cognitive function, and avocados provide B vitamins that support brain health. However, the quantities might not be sufficient to focus primarily on enhancing mental clarity.

improve_immunity.explanation: The combination of omega-3 fatty acids from salmon and the vitamins from avocado, cucumber, and spinach can bolster immunity. Mint, although used sparingly, has anti-inflammatory properties that also support immune health.

improve_mobility.explanation: Omega-3s in salmon can help with joint inflammation, and cucumber provides hydration, aiding in joint lubrication. However, the dish doesn't predominantly focus on elements that strongly enhance mobility.

detox.explanation: Cucumber, mint, and lime have mild cleansing properties that can aid in detoxifying the body, but they are not in sufficient quantities to prioritize detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: Avocado contains B vitamins which are known to enhance mood. omega-3s in salmon can also reduce stress levels, but the main focus isn't on mood enhancement in this dish.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While the healthy fats from salmon and avocado provide calming effects, sedentary meals like this are not specific to improve sleep quality.

53018.strInstructions:
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Heat a large pot over medium heat. Add the bacon and kielbasa; cook and stir until the bacon has rendered its fat and sausage is lightly browned. Use a slotted spoon to remove the meat and transfer to a large casserole or Dutch oven.

Coat the cubes of pork lightly with flour and fry them in the bacon drippings over medium-high heat until golden brown. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the pork to the casserole. Add the garlic, onion, carrots, fresh mushrooms, cabbage and sauerkraut. Reduce heat to medium; cook and stir until the carrots are soft, about 10 minutes. Do not let the vegetables brown.

Deglaze the pan by pouring in the red wine and stirring to loosen all of the bits of food and flour that are stuck to the bottom. Season with the bay leaf, basil, marjoram, paprika, salt, pepper, caraway seeds and cayenne pepper; cook for 1 minute.

Mix in the dried mushrooms, hot pepper sauce, Worcestershire sauce, beef stock, tomato paste and tomatoes. Heat through just until boiling. Pour the vegetables and all of the liquid into the casserole dish with the meat. Cover with a lid.

Bake in the preheated oven for 2 1/2 to 3 hours, until meat is very tender.

boost_metabolism.explanation: While garlic and cayenne pepper have mild metabolic-enhancing properties, they are present in limited quantities. The dish is rich in proteins and fats, particularly from the pork and bacon, which are more supportive of energy rather than directly increasing metabolic rate.

boost_energy.explanation: This stew contains a large amount of protein from pork and kielbasa, as well as carbohydrates from vegetables and flour, which can help boost energy levels. However, the energy boost is more sustained due to the heavy protein load rather than a quick revitalization.

enhance_focus.explanation: Though garlic and onion may mildly support cognitive function through improved circulation, the dish does not have pronounced brain-boosting ingredients. The focus-enhancing potential is minimal due to the savory, heavy nature of the dish mostly offering grounding rather than stimulating effects.

improve_immunity.explanation: The stew prominently features garlic and sauerkraut, known in TCM for their immune-supportive properties. Garlic, being warming and pungent, helps dispel cold and is commonly used to bolster the immune system. Sauerkraut, a fermented food, adds probiotics supportive of gut health, crucial for a strong immune response. The presence of onions and bay leaf also supports this benefit, making it the primary health advantage of this dish.

improve_mobility.explanation: The dish includes ingredients that can have mild benefits for joint health, such as garlic and onions, due to their anti-inflammatory properties, but this is not substantial enough. The heavy meat content is more aligned with nourishment rather than promoting mobility.

detox.explanation: While cabbage and sauerkraut have detoxifying qualities in TCM by promoting healthy digestion and moving through the body efficiently, the inclusion of meats and rich flavors diminishes the focus on detoxification, making this not a primary benefit.

enhance_mood.explanation: The hearty nature of the stew can provide comfort and nourishment, which may help enhance mood due to its grounding properties. However, the dish is not specifically designed to target mood enhancement, as it lacks ingredients directly linked to calming or uplifting emotional states.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: This dish is rich and hearty, which is more energizing than calming, making it unlikely to aid in sleep quality. While a heavy meal like this could potentially promote a feeling of fullness leading to drowsiness, it isn't specifically soothing or containing ingredients known to aid sleep.

52988.strInstructions:
Get everything for the pudding prepared. Chop the almonds coarsely. Peel, core and chop the cooking apples. Sharpen your knife and chop the candied peel. (You can chop the almonds and apples in a food processor, but the peel must be done by hand.) Grate three quarters of the nutmeg (sounds a lot but it's correct).

Mix the almonds, apples, candied peel, nutmeg, raisins, flour, breadcrumbs, light muscovado sugar, eggs and 2 tbsp brandy or cognac in a large bowl. 

Holding the butter in its wrapper, grate a quarter of it into the bowl, then stir everything together. Repeat until all the butter is grated, then stir for 3-4 mins – the mixture is ready when it subsides slightly after each stir. Ask the family to stir too, and get everyone to make a wish. 

Generously butter two 1.2 litre bowls and put a circle of baking parchment in the bottom of each. Pack in the pudding mixture. Cover with a double layer of baking parchment, pleating it to allow for expansion, then tie with string (keep the paper in place with a rubber band while tying). Trim off any excess paper. 

Now stand each bowl on a large sheet of foil and bring the edges up over the top, then put another sheet of foil over the top and bring it down underneath to make a double package (this makes the puddings watertight). Tie with more string, and make a handle for easy lifting in and out of the pan. Watch our video to see how to tie up a pudding correctly.

Boil or oven steam the puddings for 8 hrs, topping up with water as necessary. Remove from the pans and leave to cool overnight. When cold, discard the messy wrappings and re-wrap in new baking parchment, foil and string. Store in a cool, dry place until Christmas. 

To make the brandy butter, cream the butter with the orange zest and icing sugar. Gradually beat in the brandy or cognac and chopped stem ginger. Put in a small bowl, fork the top attractively and put in the fridge to set. The butter will keep for a week in the fridge, or it can be frozen for up to six weeks. 

On Christmas Day, boil or oven steam for 1 hr. Unwrap and turn out. To flame, warm 3-4 tbsp brandy in a small pan, pour it over the pudding and set light to it.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The recipe mainly contains high-calorie and carbohydrate-rich ingredients like muscovado sugar, breadcrumbs, and butter, which don't specifically aid metabolism boosting from a TCM perspective.

boost_energy.explanation: The almonds and eggs provide protein and healthy fats, which could offer some energy-boosting properties, but the high content of sugar might lead to energy spikes followed by drops.

enhance_focus.explanation: Nutmeg is sometimes believed to help with mental focus and clarity, but in this recipe, its effect would be minimal compared to the high sugar content and fats.

improve_immunity.explanation: Raisins, apples, and almonds are rich in vitamins, and nuts in general are seen as strengthening in TCM. The generous amount of these ingredients could contribute positively to immune function by providing antioxidant and nutrient support.

improve_mobility.explanation: The ingredients do not include specific elements that are known to benefit joint health, such as omega-3 or anti-inflammatory compounds.

detox.explanation: While apples and raisins contain fibers that assist in digestion, the recipe's high sugar and fat content counteracts any mild detoxification properties they might provide.

enhance_mood.explanation: The festive nature of the dessert and the use of brandy may have a mild positive impact on mood, but primarily through enjoyment rather than intrinsic nutrients.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: Nutmeg is sometimes used for its potential calming effects, however, its small quantity and the overall richness of the pudding could override any significant impact on sleep quality.

52882.strInstructions:
Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6 (180C fan).
Put the potatoes into a saucepan of cold salted water. Bring up to the boil and simmer until completely tender. Drain well and then mash with the butter and milk. Add pepper and taste to check the seasoning. Add salt and more pepper if necessary.
For the fish filling, melt the butter in a saucepan, add the leeks and stir over the heat. Cover with a lid and simmer gently for 10 minutes, or until soft. Measure the flour into a small bowl. Add the wine and whisk together until smooth.
Add the milk to the leeks, bring to the boil and then add the wine mixture. Stir briskly until thickened. Season and add the parsley and fish. Stir over the heat for two minutes, then spoon into an ovenproof casserole. Scatter over the eggs. Allow to cool until firm.
Spoon the mashed potatoes over the fish mixture and mark with a fork. Sprinkle with cheese.
Bake for 30-40 minutes, or until lightly golden-brown on top and bubbling around the edges.

boost_metabolism.explanation: While fish and potatoes are nutritious, there are limited specific ingredients directly associated with boosting metabolism in TCM, such as chilies or ginger.

boost_energy.explanation: Fish, especially the combination of salmon and haddock, is rich in Omega-3 fatty acids, which enhance energy levels and combat fatigue, aligning with TCM's view of nourishing 'yin' and maintaining 'qi'. Potatoes and eggs provide additional energy through complex carbohydrates and proteins.

enhance_focus.explanation: Fish is beneficial for brain health and focus due to Omega-3, but the concentration of such ingredients is moderate, and other brain-boosting herbs or ingredients are not present.

improve_immunity.explanation: The dish includes parsley and fish, which can support immunity but lacks more concentrated immunity-boosting herbs commonly used in TCM like astragalus or ginseng.

improve_mobility.explanation: Fish contains essential fatty acids beneficial for joint health, and potatoes provide important vitamins, but specific ingredients like turmeric, known for enhancing mobility, are absent.

detox.explanation: The recipe focuses more on comfort and rich flavors, with limited ingredients aimed at detoxification like green tea or other purifying herbs.

enhance_mood.explanation: Fish oils have a positive effect on mood enhancement and mental wellness, and the creamy, hearty nature of the dish provides comfort, slightly supporting emotional well-being.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: While the dish is warming and comforting, which could indirectly aid relaxation, it lacks more direct sleep-inducing ingredients like lotus seeds or jujube dates.

52870.strInstructions:
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and line a baking tray with foil. Drain the chickpeas, pat dry and tip onto the prepared baking tray. Add the oil and paprika, toss to coat, then roast for 20-25 mins until browned and crisp, shaking halfway through cooking.

Meanwhile, put the tomatoes and onion in a small bowl with the vinegar and set aside to pickle. Put the avocado in another bowl and mash with a fork, leaving some larger chunks. Stir in the lime juice and season well. Mix the soured cream with the harissa and set aside until ready to serve.

Heat a griddle pan until nearly smoking. Add the tortillas , one at a time, charring each side until hot with griddle lines. 

Put everything on the table and build the fajitas : spread a little of the harissa cream over the tortilla, top with roasted chickpeas, guacamole, pickled salsa and coriander, if you like. Serve with the lime wedges for squeezing over.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The use of chickpeas and paprika can help in improving metabolism slightly due to their nutrient-rich profiles, but these do not play a dominant role in metabolism enhancement in this dish.

boost_energy.explanation: Chickpeas are protein-rich and provide a good source of energy. Olive oil also provides healthy fats, contributing to a sustained energy supply. However, the overall energy-boosting effect is moderate.

enhance_focus.explanation: Avocado contains healthy fats which can support brain health, but their quantity is not significant enough in the recipe to considerably boost focus.

improve_immunity.explanation: Tomatoes and red onions, which are present in moderate amounts, contain vitamin C and antioxidants, supporting immune health. However, they are not emphasized in large quantities to make a significant impact.

improve_mobility.explanation: While avocado contains some nutrients beneficial for joint health, such as healthy fats, the overall composition and quantities do not significantly contribute to improved mobility.

detox.explanation: The combination of lime juice, red onions, and coriander provides a strong detoxifying effect in TCM. Lime juice and coriander are known for their cleansing properties, aiding in liver detoxification, while onions can support cardiovascular health and detoxification. The recipe uses enough of these ingredients to primarily support detoxification.

enhance_mood.explanation: Avocado helps in enhancing mood due to its healthy fat content and B vitamins, which support neurotransmitter function, yet the amount used does not make mood enhancement a primary focus.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: There is minimal direct influence on sleep quality due to the lack of prominent calming ingredients. The presence of some healthy fats may provide a calming effect, but it's not a major component of the dish.

52850.strInstructions:
Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan and cook the onion for 1-2 mins just until softened. Add the chicken and fry for 7-10 mins until cooked through and the onions have turned golden. Grate over the ginger, stir through the harissa to coat everything and cook for 1 min more.

Tip in the apricots, chickpeas and couscous, then pour over the stock and stir once. Cover with a lid or tightly cover the pan with foil and leave for about 5 mins until the couscous has soaked up all the stock and is soft. Fluff up the couscous with a fork and scatter over the coriander to serve. Serve with extra harissa, if you like.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The ginger and apricots may marginally stimulate the metabolism, but the primary ingredients like chicken and couscous do not prioritize metabolic boosting according to TCM.

boost_energy.explanation: Chickpeas and chicken provide good energy supports through protein and carbohydrates, while ginger can stimulate energy pathways.

enhance_focus.explanation: While ginger and coriander have minor benefits for enhancing mental clarity, the focus-enhancing benefits are not strongly supported by the other ingredients.

improve_immunity.explanation: The combination of ginger and onion are recognized in TCM for their ability to help ward off colds and flus, aligning well with immune support. Ginger is particularly warming and can help dispel pathogens, while onions offer a slight detoxifying effect. Chicken stock is traditionally used in broths for convalescence, and chickpeas provide a grounding, nourishing base that can bolster vitality. Altogether, the meal offers a synergistic blend of ingredients that enhance the body's immune response.

improve_mobility.explanation: The majority of ingredients do not specifically support joint or bone health from a TCM perspective.

detox.explanation: Ingredients like chickpeas and coriander can aid digestion and assist in mild detoxification, but it's not the primary function of this dish.

enhance_mood.explanation: While certain warming spices like ginger can slightly uplift mood, the dish does not focus on mood enhancement.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish includes limited ingredients known for promoting sleep, lacking calming herbs or ingredients typically associated with aiding sleep quality, such as those that nourish Yin.

52817.strMeal: Stovetop Eggplant With Harissa, Chickpeas, and Cumin Yogurt
52817.strInstructions:
Heat the oil in a 12-inch skillet over high heat until shimmering. Add the eggplants and lower the heat to medium. Season with salt and pepper as you rotate the eggplants, browning them on all sides. Continue to cook, turning regularly, until a fork inserted into the eggplant meets no resistance (you may have to stand them up on their fat end to finish cooking the thickest parts), about 20 minutes, lowering the heat and sprinkling water into the pan as necessary if the eggplants threaten to burn or smoke excessively.

2.
Mix the harissa, chickpeas and tomatoes together, then add to the eggplants. Cook until the tomatoes have blistered and broken down, about 5 minutes more. Season with salt and pepper and add water as necessary to thin to a saucy consistency. Meanwhile, combine the yogurt and cumin in a serving bowl. Season with salt and pepper.

3.
Top the eggplant mixture with the parsley, drizzle with more extra virgin olive oil, and serve with the yogurt on the side.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The combination of spices and healthy fats from olive oil can slightly boost metabolism. However, the primary ingredients, such as eggplants and chickpeas, do not have strong metabolism-boosting properties.

boost_energy.explanation: The chickpeas provide a good source of plant-based protein and complex carbohydrates, which can supply sustained energy. However, this is not the main focus of the dish.

enhance_focus.explanation: While some ingredients like cumin may have mild cognitive benefits, the quantity and combination of ingredients are not strongly aligned with focus enhancement.

improve_immunity.explanation: The ingredients, particularly eggplants, tomatoes, and chickpeas, are rich in antioxidants and vitamins that support the immune system. In TCM, eggplant is considered cooling and detoxifying, which helps balance the body's functions and strengthens immunity. Tomatoes are high in vitamins A and C, which are crucial for immune health, and chickpeas provide zinc and other vital nutrients. Parsley offers additional vitamin C and antioxidants, further reinforcing this benefit.

improve_mobility.explanation: The anti-inflammatory properties of olive oil and the potential joint health benefits of parsley add some value, but the primary focus is not on improving mobility.

detox.explanation: Eggplants and parsley both have mild detoxifying properties. However, detoxification is not the primary focus of the dish, as the cooking method and other ingredients do not support this benefit significantly.

enhance_mood.explanation: The presence of yogurt and parsley can have a slight mood-enhancing effect. However, the overall composition of the dish does not emphasize mood enhancement, thereby yielding a moderate score.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The dish includes cumin, which can have a soothing effect, but overall, the dish's composition does not prominently feature sleep-inducing ingredients.

52932.strInstructions:
In a large bowl, with an electric mixer, mix the butter and sugar till the mix is light.
Add eggs and vanilla and mix.
In another bowl, mix flour and baking powder.
Alternate flour mix and milk to the butter mix.
Pour into a 13 inch by 9 inch greased pan.
MAPLE SAUCE.
In a large casserole, bring to boil the syrup, brown sugar, cream and butter and constantly stir.
Reduce heat and and gently cook 2 minutes or till sauce has reduced a little bit.
Pour sauce gently over cake.
Bake at 325°f (160°c) about 35 minutes or till cake is light brown and when toothpick inserted comes out clean.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The dessert contains high amounts of sugar and butter, which provide quick energy, but not through metabolism-boosting pathways. The presence of eggs could contribute slightly to metabolism support through their protein content, but overall, this is not a significant metabolism-enhancing dish.

boost_energy.explanation: Due to the high sugar content from sugar, maple syrup, and brown sugar, this dessert provides a quick energy boost. Although not sustained energy, according to TCM, sugar can provide immediate energy to the Spleen Qi, which is responsible for energy distribution.

enhance_focus.explanation: While sugar can provide a temporary surge in concentration, it can also lead to a crash, which does not support sustained focus. The lack of specific brain-enhancing ingredients keeps this score low.

improve_immunity.explanation: The ingredients in this dessert do not particularly support immune health. Common immune-boosting ingredients like ginger, garlic, or medicinal mushrooms are absent.

improve_mobility.explanation: There are no TCM ingredients included that would traditionally support joint flexibility or bone health. The recipe is more about energy provision rather than mobility support.

detox.explanation: High sugar and fat content do not aid detoxification in TCM, which usually recommends bitter and cooling foods for this purpose.

enhance_mood.explanation: Sweet flavors in TCM can boost mood temporarily by nourishing the Spleen, but due to potential post-consumption sugar crashes, this effect is not sustained. However, desserts are often associated with emotional comfort and pleasure.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: This dessert lacks specific calming or sleep-inducing ingredients like jujube seeds or lotus seeds, and the sugar content might actually disturb restful sleep.

53035.strInstructions:
STEP 1
Peel and cut the potatoes into even, medium-sized chunks. Put in a large pan filled with cold salted water, bring to the boil and cook for 10-15 mins until a knife can be inserted into the potatoes easily.

STEP 2
Meanwhile, melt the butter in a large sauté pan over a medium heat. Add the garlic, cabbage, spring onions and some seasoning. Stir occasionally until the cabbage is wilted but still retains a little bite, then set aside.

STEP 3
Drain the potatoes, leave to steam-dry for a couple of mins, then mash with the cream, mustard and seasoning in the same saucepan. Stir in the cabbage and ham hock. Keep warm over a low heat.

STEP 4
Reheat the pan you used to cook the cabbage (no need to wash first), add a splash of oil, crack in the eggs and fry to your liking. To serve, divide the colcannon between bowls and top each with a fried egg.

boost_metabolism.explanation: Mustard can have a mild warming effect on the body, which in TCM is thought to support metabolism. However, the warming properties of mustard are not present in significant quantities. The overall dish contains heavier elements like potato and cream, which are not specifically metabolism enhancing.

boost_energy.explanation: The combination of carbohydrates from potatoes and protein from ham and eggs provides a substantial source of energy. From a TCM perspective, potatoes (a root vegetable) strengthen the Spleen and Stomach, contributing to overall energy and vitality. Ham, a rich source of Qi-building nutrients, complements this by providing protein and fats. The inclusion of cabbage and garlic also adds to the yang or warming energy of the dish, supporting overall vitality.

enhance_focus.explanation: While eggs are known to help with brain health due to lecithin, the dish overall does not focus on ingredients that specifically aim to enhance focus or mental clarity. The primary ingredients, potato and ham, do not support brain-boosting properties in TCM.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic is known for boosting the immune system due to its warming nature and ability to expel toxins. However, the presence of garlic is limited by its quantity. Cabbage also helps in supporting wei qi (defensive energy), but the overall impact on immunity is moderate.

improve_mobility.explanation: This dish does not focus on bone or joint health. The presence of protein from ham provides some support for tissues, but the primary ingredients do not have a direct influence on improving mobility.

detox.explanation: Cabbage can aid in detoxification processes due to its cleansing properties, but its role in this dish is relatively minor compared to carbohydrates like potato and rich fats, which do not support detoxification directly.

enhance_mood.explanation: Eggs and ham contain nutrients that might support mood regulation. The warming nature of butter and garlic might also lend a comforting effect, but this is secondary to its primary energy-boosting qualities.

aid_sleep_quality.explanation: The significant amount of energy-providing ingredients like potatoes and ham might not be conducive to promoting restful sleep, despite the presence of calming ingredients like butter, which have minor sleep-support properties.

52885.strInstructions:
Melt the fat in a non-stick pan, allow it to get nice and hot, then add the bacon. As it begins to brown, add the onion and garlic. Next, add the sliced sprouts or cabbage and let it colour slightly. All this will take 5-6 mins.
Next, add the potato. Work everything together in the pan and push it down so that the mixture covers the base of the pan – allow the mixture to catch slightly on the base of the pan before turning it over and doing the same again. It’s the bits of potato that catch in the pan that define the term ‘bubble and squeak’, so be brave and let the mixture colour. Cut into wedges and serve.

boost_metabolism.explanation: The garlic and cabbage in the recipe can mildly stimulate metabolism. However, the predominant ingredients such as potatoes and bacon are more energy-dense, which might not significantly boost metabolism as they are heavier and not traditionally aligned with weight management in TCM.

boost_energy.explanation: With a substantial quantity of potatoes and bacon, this dish is energy-dense, providing caloric energy. Garlic and onion are also invigorating, though the high carbohydrate content largely provides physical energy rather than Qi (vital energy) boosting from a TCM perspective.

enhance_focus.explanation: Garlic and onions may have slight cognitive enhancing properties in TCM due to their ability to invigorate Qi, but their influence is not strong in promoting focus relative to other benefits this dish offers.

improve_immunity.explanation: Garlic and onions are traditionally considered in TCM as potent ingredients to bolster Wei Qi, the defense energy, similar to boosting immunity. Brussels sprouts, being cruciferous, also contribute significantly to cleansing and supporting detoxification, which aids immunity. Therefore, the combined action of these ingredients primarily supports the immune system.

improve_mobility.explanation: There is limited support to suggest this dish enhances joint flexibility or mobility. Ingredients like cabbage might support detoxification processes that indirectly contribute to joint health, but not substantially enough.

detox.explanation: Brussels sprouts and garlic contribute to detoxification processes, aiding the liver Qi in TCM. However, the presence of heavier ingredients like bacon and butter somewhat counteracts the detox benefit.

enhance_mood.explanation: While onions and garlic can have invigorating properties and contribute to mood enhancement in TCM, their effects are mild compared to other mood-supporting herbs and foods.
